questions.text: Umesh, a 35-year-old male, presents to the outpatient department of Dr Mehta’s Hospitals, Chennai with intermittent fever, chills, and sweating for the past 10 days. He had recently returned from a 2-week trip to the Sundarbans, a forested region known for its endemicity with malaria. Laboratory investigations confirm the diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum malaria, which is sensitive to chloroquine. Dr Dileep Kumar, the treating physician is planning to ensure a radical cure to prevent future relapses. Which of the following is the drug of choice for radical cure of malaria in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chloroquine

 

  • Radical cure in the context of malaria means eradication of both liver stages and blood stages of the parasite to prevent future relapses.
  • For Plasmodium falciparum, the main concern is the blood stages as it doesn't have a dormant liver phase (like P. vivax and P. ovale).
  • Chloroquine is the drug of choice for treating chloroquine-sensitive Plasmodium falciparum blood stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B & C: ACTs (Artemisinin-based Combination Therapies), like Artesunate + Sulfadoxine/Pyrimethamine and Artemether + Lumefantrine, are primarily used in areas with chloroquine-resistant strains of P. falciparum.

 

Option D: Primaquine is primarily used for the radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale because it targets the dormant liver stages (hypnozoites) of these species. It is not the DOC for radical cure of P. falciparum which doesn't have hypnozoites.

choices.text: Norepinephrine plus phentolamine
Dopamine (at a very high dose)
Ephedrine plus propranolol
Phenylephrine plus atropine

questions.text: During your rural posting after the internship, you encounter a patient of acute cardiac failure. Your preferred drug for this condition is dobutamine. However, it is not available there. Which of the following other drugs, or combination of drugs, would be a suitable alternative, giving the pharmacologic equivalent of what you want the dobutamine to do?
questions.solution:
Ans A) Norepinephrine plus phentolamine

 

Dobutamine's primary action is increased cardiac contractility due to β1 stimulation without substantially increasing heart rate or systemic vascular resistance. The desired effects in acute heart failure would be improved cardiac output without significantly raising systemic vascular resistance, which would further tax the heart.

 

  • Norepinephrine is an agonist of alpha 1, alpha 2 and beta 1 receptors. It increases systemic vascular resistance significantly through α1 agonism and also increases cardiac contractility and heart rate through β1 agonism.
  • Phentolamine is a non-selective α-adrenergic antagonist that would counteract the vasoconstrictive effects of norepinephrine.
  • The combination would lead to increased cardiac contractility and possibly heart rate without substantial increases in vascular resistance. By antagonising the alpha 1 and alpha 2 actions of norepinephrine by phentolamine, this combination gives only beta 1 action that closely mimics the effects of dobutamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dopamine (at a very high dose):

 

  • At high doses, dopamine stimulates α-adrenergic receptors leading to vasoconstriction. While dopamine can increase cardiac contractility at intermediate doses, at very high doses, the increased systemic vascular resistance due to α-adrenergic stimulation does not mimic the action of dobutamine.

 

Option C. Ephedrine plus propranolol:

 

  • This combination would not mimic the action of dobutamine as desired.

 

Option D. Phenylephrine plus atropine:

 

  • This combination would primarily increase heart rate (from atropine) and systemic vascular resistance (from phenylephrine) without having a primary effect on cardiac contractility.

questions.text: Dr. Apurv Mehra is managing a 45-year-old patient named Rakesh, who presents with recurring episodes of joint pain and inflammation. After a thorough assessment, Dr. Mehra diagnoses him with hyperuricemia predisposing to gout. To better understand the patient's uric acid metabolism, the doctor decides to measure the total amount of uric acid. After receiving the baseline measurements, Rakesh is prescribed an "antigout" medication. Several weeks into the therapy, Dr. Mehra repeats the 24-hour urine uric acid measurement to evaluate the drug's effectiveness. He observes a significant reduction in the urate content in the post-treatment sample. Throughout the treatment period, Rakesh confirms no new health concerns, and he assures Dr. Mehra that his daily proteins and purine intake remains unchanged. Given these observations, which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to Rakesh?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol acts by inhibiting xanthine oxidase, which is responsible for the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and then xanthine to uric acid. By reducing the synthesis of uric acid, less uric acid is produced and therefore, less is available for excretion in the urine. This aligns with the observed reduction in the post-treatment urine sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Probenecid: Probenecid is a uricosuric drug, which means it increases the excretion of uric acid in the urine. Given that the patient's uric acid level in the urine decreased, it is unlikely that probenecid was the drug administered.

 

Option C. Colchicine: Colchicine is primarily used for the treatment of acute gout attacks. It works by decreasing inflammation. However, it doesn't have a significant direct effect on the production or excretion of uric acid.

 

Option D. Indomethacin: Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). While it is sometimes used to manage pain and inflammation during acute gout attacks, it doesn't significantly affect the production or excretion of uric acid.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of recurrent headaches, vomiting. Parents report that the headaches have been progressively worsening over the past few weeks, and the vomiting episodes are occurring almost daily. They are also concerned about the child's developmental delay, noting a significant loss of previously acquired skills such as speaking in full sentences and walking steadily. On physical examination, the child's head circumference is noted to be above the 97th percentile for his age, with a tense and bulging anterior fontanelle. The child exhibits the "sunsetting" sign, where the sclera is visible above the irises when looking downward. Additionally, he has an unsteady gait and difficulty walking without support. MRI is shown here. What is the likely cause of hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tectal glioma

MRI is showing an isointense lesion at the tectum with associated dilation of the ventricles, consistent with hydrocephalus as described by the clinical scenario.

choices.text: Should not change the antidepressant as initial response is good

questions.text: A 37-year-old female with a medical history significant for hypertension and seizure disorder has been undergoing treatment for major depressive disorder. She was initially prescribed fluoxetine, which resulted in significant clinical improvement in her depressive symptoms. However, she now reports experiencing bothersome sexual side effects, specifically a marked decrease in libido. The psychiatrist considers switching her medication. Which of the following is the best advise for the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Switch to Mirtazapine


Mirtazapine is an appropriate option in this case for several reasons. First, it is less likely to cause sexual side effects compared to SSRIs. Second, it does not lower the seizure threshold, making it safer for patients with a history of seizure disorder. Third, it doesn't have the hypertensive side effects associated with some other options like venlafaxine. While mirtazapine can cause weight gain and sedation, these side effects might be more manageable than the risks posed by the other medications listed.

choices.text: Medical institutions can only be held responsible for the actions of their employed medical professionals if institution had direct knowledge of the negligence.
Vicarious liability does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence, as such actions are considered beyond the scope of their employment.
Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution
Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice.

questions.text: In the realm of medical practice, the principle of vicarious liability plays a crucial role in determining legal responsibility. Which of the following statements best exemplifies the concept of vicarious liability in cases of medical negligence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution

 

In the context of medical negligence, vicarious liability means that a healthcare institution, such as a hospital or clinic, can be held legally responsible for the actions or omissions of its medical professionals if those actions occurred within the scope of their employment. This holds true even if the institution itself did not directly contribute to the negligence.

While it's more common to apply vicarious liability to employees, there are situations where independent contractors can also trigger vicarious liability, especially if they are integrated into the institution's operations to a significant extent.

 

Other Options

 

  1. Vicarious liability is not dependent on institution's knowledge of negligence. Employer can be held responsible for the actions of their employees or agents (within the scope of their employment), regardless of the employer's knowledge of those actions.
  2. Vicarious liability applies as long as negligent actions occurred within the scope of employment, irrespective of whether the negligence is considered "gross" or not. Nature of negligence, whether ordinary or gross, does not matter for applying vicarious liability.
  3. Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice.
    Possession of a valid license doesn't exempt medical institutions from vicarious liability. Even if a licensed professional commits negligence, the principle of vicarious liability can still hold the employer liable for the actions of their employee or agent.

choices.text: In bag laparoscopic morcellation of the specimen
Mini-laparotomy and remove the specimen
Laser fulguration of the specimen

questions.text: You are assisting the gynaecologist in a total laparoscopic hysterectomy for a 45year old woman with multiple uterine fibroids. The uterus is about 18 weeks size of a gravid uterus, and you wonder how the gynaecologist will manage to take the entire uterus out once the hysterectomy is complete. Which of the following is not a technique of specimen removal following a laparoscopic hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Laser fulguration of the specimen

 

Specimen removal in laparoscopy hysterectomy can be done by

 

  1. Vaginal retrieval. In large uteruses > 12 weeks, vaginal morcellation using a morcellator or using a coring technique can be done
  2. In bag laparoscopic morcellation can be done, by placing the entire specimen in an endo-bag and then morcellating. This is preferred over morcellation without an endo-bag as if there is a leiomyosarcoma, this can get disseminated
  3. Another way of removing the specimen, is to make a small abdominal incision (mini-laparotomy) and take the specimen out.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient undergoing orthopedic surgery for a femur fracture starts to develop tachycardia and hypercarbia. The anesthesiologist initiates treatment with dantrolene. Genetic testing is recommended to identify the genetic basis of this disease in the patient. Which of the following chromosomes is responsible for this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chromosome 19

 

The primary genetic mutation associated with Malignant hyperthermia susceptibility is located on chromosome 19, specifically in the RYR1 gene, which codes for the ryanodine receptor found in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscle cells. Mutations in this gene can lead to uncontrolled calcium release, which plays a central role in the pathophysiology of MH.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the dentist by their parents due to facial swelling, which has been progressively increasing over the past year. The swelling is bilateral and involves the lower jaw. On examination, there is no pain or tenderness associated with the swelling. Dental radiographs are shown here. The child's dental development is otherwise normal. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cherubism

 

Cherubism is a rare genetic disorder characterized by bilateral, painless, and symmetrical swelling of the lower jaw, which gives affected individuals a cherubic or "chipmunk-like" appearance. Radiographically, it presents with multilocular, radiolucent lesions primarily affecting the mandible, often involving the molar and premolar regions showing a soap-bubble appearance. Cherubism typically begins in childhood and stabilizes or regresses after puberty. Cherubism is a rare autosomal dominant disorder of the jaws caused by mutation of the SH3BP2 gene. The bone is replaced by a fibrous granuloma containing multinucleated giant cells.

choices.text: Discontinue valproate immediately and advise her to avoid concurrent use of NSAIDs and fluoroquinolones in the future
Taper off valproate over a week and introduce a different AED for long-term management
Continue valproate, but switch her osteoarthritis medication from diclofenac to paracetamol
Restart moxifloxacin under observation to confirm if it was indeed the causative factor for the seizure.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman from a rural area presented to a local practitioner with a 3-day history of cough and fever. She had been taking diclofenac twice daily for osteoarthritis. The practitioner prescribed moxifloxacin, assuming an upper respiratory tract infection. Although her symptoms of fever and cough improved, on the third day of treatment, she experienced a generalized tonic-clonic seizure (GTCS). The same practitioner diagnosed her with grand mal epilepsy and advised her to start valproate for 3 years. After taking first dose of valproate she developed vomiting and gastric upset. Worried, she contacted her son, a medical student at MAMC, Delhi. He recalled a lecture by Dr. GOGA and persuaded her to seek a second opinion. Comprehensive evaluations at MAMC, including a CT scan and EEG, showed no abnormalities. What should be the immediate step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Discontinue valproate immediately and advise her to avoid concurrent use of NSAIDs and fluoroquinolones in the future.

 

Explanation:

  • The interaction between diclofenac (an NSAID) and moxifloxacin (a fluoroquinolone) has the potential to lower the seizure threshold, which is the probable cause for her GTCS episode.
  • As all other investigations (like the CT scan and EEG) did not reveal any inherent pathology and considering her recent medication history, the seizure is most likely a result of the drug interaction. Moreover, the immediate adverse reactions to valproate further suggest it's not suitable for her. Thus, the logical step would be to discontinue valproate and ensure she avoids such drug combinations in the future.

questions.text: A 15y girl is brought by her mother to the OPD. She says that her daughter has not yet attained menarche. She has been doing well in school and is on the school basketball team. However, her mother has noticed her voice has deepened and there is coarse hair growth on the chin since a few months. When you examine her, you find there is no breast development. There is sparse pubic and axillary hair and on local examination you find there is an enlarged clitoris. A karyotype done, reveals 46XY and an ultrasound reveals an absent uterus. Which is the most likely possibility?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 5 α reductase deficiency

  • This is most likely 5 α reductase deficiency
    • There is failure of conversion of testosterone to 5DHT
    • Classical presentation:
    • External genitalia: predominantly female at birth; so usually reared as female.
    • Internal genitalia: Male (The epididymis, the vas deferens, seminal vesicles and ejaculatory ducts form but empty into a short blind vagina)
    • Testis: Located in the inguinal canal
    • At Puberty: Virilization of varying degrees starts.
    • Affected patients:  develop a normal muscle mass, libido, deepening of voice (Testosterone dependent) but have less body hair, less temporal hairline recession, no acne (All these are DHT dependent)
    • Suspect in adolescence with the characteristic phenotype and a serum hormonal profile showing normal male level testosterone and an increased testosterone/ DHT ratio)
       
  • In Swyer syndrome
    • This is a form of 46XY gonadal dysgenesis
    • Both male and female internal genitalia are present
    • External genitalia is female
    • Patients present as primary amenorrhoea with no secondary sexual characters
       
  • Complete Androgen Insensitivity syndrome
    • This is a 46XY which presents as primary amenorrhoea with no internal or external male genitalia
    • The external genitalia is female
    • Pubic hair and axillary hair are absent
    • Breast development is present due to peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogen
       
  • Reifenstein syndrome
    • 46XY
    • This is a milder form of androgen insensitivity syndrome
    • Presents as ambiguous genitalia (under-virilized male) or as male infertility

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a recent road traffic accident. He was involved in a high-speed collision and sustained blunt trauma to his abdomen and lower back. He complains of severe left-sided flank pain and haematuria. This was managed conservatively in view of AAST Grade 2 injury on CECT. During his in-patient stay, it was noticed that his BP is increasing while he was previously normotensive. His Baseline CECT is shown here. What is the likely explanation for his course?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Page kidney

 

Page kidney is a medical condition characterized by the compression or external pressure on the kidney, often caused by the accumulation of fluid or blood in the space surrounding the kidney, known as the perinephric space. This external pressure can lead to decreased blood flow to the kidney and, consequently, impaired kidney function.

 

The most common cause of Page kidney is the accumulation of blood in the perinephric space following a traumatic injury. However, Page kidney can also occur due to other conditions, such as: Renal artery stenosis, Renal tumors or cysts or Infections.

 

Symptoms of Page kidney may include: Flank pain, Hypertension, Decreased urine output or Kidney dysfunction or failure

 

Treatment of Page kidney often involves addressing the underlying cause of external compression.

As told by neighbours, the deceased person didn’t interact much with others and was a very quiet person. The dead body was brought for postmortem examination, and following injuries were seen as shown below:

 

 

Based on above context which statement is true?

There are no tentative cuts in 1st picture (cut throat wound). There are self inflicted cuts on front of forearm in 2nd picture but they are old healed injuries. May be in past the person tried to commit suicide, but at present he died due to murder.

Supraorbital margin and lower margin of external acoustic meatus

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency room with complaints of severe headaches and visual disturbances for the past week. She describes the headaches as throbbing in nature, located mainly around her temples and forehead. The visual disturbances include blurred vision and seeing "flashing lights" in her peripheral vision. She has no significant medical history but mentions that her brother has a history of similar symptoms. On detailed neurological examination reveals bilateral papilledema on fundoscopic examination. Further evaluation, including neuroimaging, confirms the presence of an intracranial mass. The radiologist takes measurements and identifies the location of the mass relative to the patient's skull using a reference point known as Frankfurt's plane. This plane passes through?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Infraorbital margin and upper margin of external acoustic meatus

 

2 lines are used for anatomical position of skull:

  • Frankfurt’s plane: Imaginary line passing from Infraorbital margin and upper margin of external acoustic meatus.
  • B- Reid’s base line: Imaginary line passing from Infraorbital margin and centre of external acoustic meatus.

choices.text: Developing countries pyramid shows low young age dependency due to lesser fertility
Developed countries pyramid shows inverted triangle due to large number of geriatric population
Developing countries pyramid is asymmetric indicative of unfavourable sex ratio
Developed countries pyramid span is higher indicating lower life expectancy

questions.text: Correct statement about Population (age-sex) Pyramid is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Developing countries pyramid is asymmetric indicative of unfavourable sex ratio

  • Shape of population pyramid indicates fertility pattern
    • Broad base, Narrow top (upright triangle): High proportion of younger population (developing countries) indicating higher young age dependency
    • Bulge in Middle, Spindle shape: High proportion of adults (developed Countries) in economically productive age group
       
  • Span (height) of population pyramid indicates life expectancy
    • Taller pyramid: Higher life expectancy (developed countries)
    • Shorter pyramid: Lower life expectancy (developing countries)
       
  • Symmetry of population pyramid indicates sex ratio
    • Symmetric pyramid: Ideal sex ratio (developed countries)
    • Asymmetric pyramid: Unfavourable sex ratio <1000 (developing countries) as they have lesser proportion of females

questions.text: Chetan, a patient in the emergency department, presents with severe drug-induced hypotension, registering a blood pressure of 75/50 mmHg. Over the years, you have managed acute hypotension from various causes using an intravenous injection of x mg of methoxamine. Given Chetan's medical history of taking his current medication for several months, and considering he shows no signs of volume depletion or hemorrhage, you administer the standard dose of methoxamine. Surprisingly, Chetan's response is unexpected and intense, causing his blood pressure to soar to 180/110 mmHg. Given this stark elevation in blood pressure post-administration, which of the following medications did Chetan most likely overdose on?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Reserpine

 

Chronic use of reserpine depletes the storage of catecholamines in presynaptic vesicles, leading to reduced neurotransmitter release. As a compensatory mechanism, the body upregulates postjunctional α1-adrenergic receptors. When an α1-adrenergic agonist like methoxamine is administered, the response is intensified due to these upregulated receptors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is evaluated for a 4-day history of chest pain and cough productive of green sputum. Medical history is significant for heart failure and coronary artery disease. She has not recently taken antibiotics or been hospitalized. Medications are furosemide, lisinopril, metoprolol, and aspirin. On physical examination, temperature is 38.1 °C (100.6 °F) and pulse rate is 96/min; blood pressure and respiration rate are normal. Oxygen saturation  is 94% breathing ambient air. Crackles are heard at the left lung base. Rapid influenza molecular assay is positive for influenza A. COVID-19 testing is negative. A chest radiograph shows left lower lobe consolidation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oseltamivir, Cefuroxime and azithromycin

 

The most appropriate treatment for this patient is antiviral therapy, with oseltamivir, combined with standard community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) combination antibiotic treatment, with azithromycin and cefuroxime axetil (Option D). Viral infections, including influenza, are commonly identified in patients with CAP; in one large study, a viral pathogen or copathogens were identified in 27% of CAP infections. Treatment with an antiviral agent such as oseltamivir has been shown to decrease the duration of symptoms and, in hospitalized patients, decrease mortality associated with influenza. Although most studies showing benefit have been performed in hospitalized patients, the 2019 Infectious Diseases Society of America and American Thoracic Society CAP guideline extrapolates the beneficial effects of antiviral therapy to outpatients with influenza and CAP. Treatment is most efficacious when given within the first 48 hours after symptom onset; however, some benefit is likely conferred even after this time, and guidelines specify that antiviral therapy should be prescribed irrespective of site of treatment or duration of illness

 

Levofloxacin monotherapy would not treat this patient's concomitant influenza, so it is not the best choice (Option A)

 

Bacterial pneumonia concurrent with or following influenza infection is common. Postinfluenza CAP has been associated with Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus pyogenes infections. For this reason, bacterial treatment for CAP should be initiated even when influenza is identified, so oseltamivir alone would not be appropriate (Option B)

 

This patient had relatively mild pneumonia that does not require hospitalization. In an otherwise healthy patient, oseltamivir and azithromycin would be appropriate, assuming pneumococcal resistance to macrolides is less than 25% in the local community (Option C). Without knowing local susceptibility patterns, macrolide monotherapy for CAP is not appropriate. Additionally, macrolide monotherapy is not appropriate in patients with significant comorbidities, such as this patient with heart failure. Instead, combination therapy with a β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor and a macrolide or doxycycline, or monotherapy with a respiratory fluoroquinolone are recommended.

choices.text: CT scan of the right lower extremity
Immediate surgical intervention with incision and direct visualization of potentially infected tissue

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with right leg swelling and pain. The patient denies trauma to the leg and reports it was normal yesterday. Examination of the right lower extremity is significant for extreme tenderness to palpation, erythema, and edema extending up to the knee. X-ray of the right leg shows tissue swelling without gas or osteomyelitis. The patient’s vital signs are normal and he is started on broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and insulin. An hour later the patient’s heart rate increases to 125 beats per minute and the erythema has progressed to the thigh with new blister formation on the leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Immediate surgical intervention with incision and direct visualization of potentially infected tissue

 

This patient’s presentation is deeply concerning for a necrotizing soft tissue infection. The rapid progression of the erythema, bullae formation, and the tachycardia mandates immediate surgical intervention. During surgery an incision is made overlying the area of suspicion and the deep soft tissue, fascia, and underlying muscle are directly visualized. All affected areas are completely resected. Radiologic studies should not be undertaken in patients in whom the diagnosis is seriously considered as they delay surgical intervention and often provide confusing information.

questions.text: This is a schematic diagram depicting body structure of which of these helminthes?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Brugia malayi

choices.text: Virat recorded a decrease in MBP but Kishor recorded an increase in MBP
Virat recorded an increase in MBP but Kishor recorded a decrease in MBP
Virat and Kishor both recorded an increase in MBP
Virat and Kishor both recorded a decrease in MBP

questions.text: Virat and Kishor were asked to demonstrate in dogs the role of sinus nerve in hypovolemic shock. Virat severed the sinus nerve when the mean blood pressure (MBP) was 85 mm Hg and Kishor cut the sinus nerve when the mean blood pressure was 55 mm Hg. On cutting the sinus nerve:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Virat recorded an increase in MBP but Kishor recorded a decrease in MBP.

 

The sinus nerve, also known as the carotid sinus nerve or glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), is involved in regulating blood pressure.

 

Baroreceptors in the carotid sinus sense changes in blood pressure and transmit this information through the sinus nerve to the brainstem's cardiovascular control centre.

 

When blood pressure is high, increased sinus nerve activity triggers a parasympathetic response, leading to reduced heart rate and vasodilation, aiming to lower blood pressure.

 

Conversely, when blood pressure is low, decreased sinus nerve activity → decreased parasympathetic and increased sympathetic activity, → vasoconstriction and increased HR to raise blood pressure.

 

In the given scenario, Virat cut the sinus nerve when the MBP was 85 mm Hg. This disruption would decrease the parasympathetic influence and increase sympathetic activity, which could raise blood pressure (Virat records an increase in MBP).

 

Kishor cut the sinus nerve when the MBP was 55 mm Hg →  decreased sympathetic activity and increased parasympathetic activity, potentially lowering blood pressure (Kishor records a decrease in MBP).

 

The actions of the sinus nerve and baroreceptors are part of the autonomic control mechanisms that maintain blood pressure stability.

A-Lacunar ligament, B-Inguinal ligament, C-Pectineal ligament
A-Pectineal ligament, B-Inguinal ligament, C-Lacunar ligament

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a complaint of a painful lump in her right groin that has been gradually increasing in size over the past few weeks. She describes the pain as constant and sharp, exacerbated when she coughs or strains. The patient has a history of multiple pregnancies and has noticed a bulge in her groin area when lifting heavy objects. On examination, there is a tender, firm, and irreducible mass in the right femoral region just below the inguinal ligament. The overlying skin appears erythematous. The patient's vital signs are stable. Proper diagnosis was made with all clinical examination and surgical treatment was decided.  During this surgery it became very important to identify the pectineal ligament, lacunar ligament & inguinal ligament. Identify the ligaments in image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-Inguinal ligament, B-Pectineal ligament, C-Lacunar ligament

 

A-Inguinal ligament

 

B-Pectineal ligament

 

C-Lacunar ligament

 

The most likely diagnosis in this case is a Femoral Hernia.

 

Femoral hernias are more common in women, especially those who have had multiple pregnancies. They are prone to incarceration and strangulation, which can lead to severe complications. Therefore, prompt surgical intervention is usually necessary to repair the hernia and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents to a psychiatrist two months after a tragic car accident in which his son died. He was driving the car with his son in the passenger seat at the time of the accident. Since then, he reports constant sadness, frequent crying spells, and inability to go to work. He also describes feeling extremely guilty and has been having thoughts of killing himself. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Major depressive disorder

  1. Normal grief: Grief is a natural emotional response to loss and is characterized by feelings of sadness, yearning, and preoccupation with the deceased. However, the symptoms this man is experiencing exceed what would typically be expected for normal grief. Particularly, suicidal ideation is not a feature of normal grief.
  2. Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD): Although the patient was involved in a traumatic event, the hallmark symptoms of PTSD such as re-experiencing the traumatic event (e.g., flashbacks), emotional numbness, and hyperarousal are not present in this case.
  3. Adjustment disorder: This is a psychiatric diagnosis that could occur in response to a stressor, but the symptoms typically appear within three months of the stressor and are less severe. Moreover, suicidal ideation suggests a more severe condition.
  4. Major depressive disorder: The patient’s symptoms such as persistent sadness, withdrawal from work, extreme guilt, and particularly suicidal ideation that have lasted for over two weeks meet the criteria for major depressive disorder. Given the severity and duration of symptoms, this is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to a history of recurrent infections, easy bruising, and persistent lymphadenopathy. The child's parents report that the lymph nodes have been enlarged for several months and are not painful. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated levels of double-negative T cells (CD3+, CD4-, CD8-) in the peripheral blood. The child has a history of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS)

 

ALPS is a rare disorder characterized by lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias (such as anemia and thrombocytopenia), and elevated levels of double-negative T cells (CD3+, CD4-, CD8-) in the peripheral blood. Mutations in the Fas receptor gene, involved in regulating apoptosis, are associated with ALPS. Options A, B, and D are other immunodeficiency disorders that do not typically manifest with the specific clinical features and laboratory findings described in the case.

Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of C, which is causing compression of B; resulting in downward gaze.
Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of B, which is causing compression of C; resulting in downward gaze.
Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of A, which is causing compression of B; resulting in downward gaze.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with diplopia. Neurological examination reveals that he has difficulty in looking upward. On radiological examination a mass was found on dorsum of brain which was compressing the nearby structure. Which of the following statement is true in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Most probably this patient is presenting with tumour of A, which is causing compression of B; resulting in downward gaze.

  • This is a case of Dorsal Mid brain syndrome known as “Perinaud’s syndrome.
  • It is characterised by Pineal gland (A) tumour “Pinealoma”
  • Pineal gland is located just above the superior colliculus hence tumour of pineal gland results in compression of superior colliculus (B)
  • Superior colliculus is responsible for upward gaze. That’s why it’s  compression results in loss of upward gaze.

  • Colliculi are elevations in brainstem. These are very important landmarks for identification of various cranial nerve nuclei location.

 

  • Superior and inferior colliculi are combined known as corpora quadragemina Q.
  • Facial colliculus is formed due to winding of VII nerve fibres over VI nerve nuclei.

questions.text: 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to an eye injury. The patient was helping his father to mow the lawn when a flying object struck his left eye. He has had foreign body sensation, pain, excessive tearing, and decreased vision in the eye. His father noticed noticed the eye being red but did not visualize any foreign objects. The patient has no other medical condtions and takes no medications. In the emergency department, the patient appears in obvious discomfort and keeps the left eye closed. Which of the following findings is most suggestive of globe perforation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fixed teardrop pupil

 

This patient had a high-velocity projectile injury to the eye; however, the object is not identified on inspection raising the possibility of open globe laceration (OGL) with an intraocular foreign body. OGL is typically caused by small, high-velocity particles (eg, metal shards) sent airborne by power tools, explosions (including weapons), lawn mowers, or motor vehicle accidents. Penetration of the globe most commonly occurs at the cornea

 

Large OGL may present with globe deformity, extrusion of vitreous or iris, or a visible entry wound. In the absence of an obvious wound, OGL may be inferred by a peaked or teardrop pupil (iris stretching due to the laceration or foreign object), increased or decreased anterior chamber depth, or reduced intraocular pressure. Other potential manifestations include loss of visual acuity or absent afferent pupillary response. If OGL is suspected, further assessment should be performed with fluorescein drops; as aqueous drains through the puncture site, fluorescein may be seen streaming away from the site or clear fluid may be seen flowing through the fluorescein.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent episodes of joint pain, swelling, and rash. The rash appears as erythematous, scaly plaques over the cheeks and buttocks. The child's parents mention that these symptoms seem to flare up periodically and are associated with fever. Physical examination reveals synovitis in multiple joints, and eye examination shows uveitis. Genetic testing is performed, revealing a mutation in the NOD2 gene. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Blau Syndrome

 

Explanation: Blau syndrome is a rare autoinflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of arthritis, skin rash, and uveitis. The distinctive feature of Blau syndrome is the presence of granulomatous inflammation affecting the joints, skin, and eyes. Mutations in the NOD2 gene are associated with this condition. Options A, B, and D do not typically manifest with the triad of symptoms described in the case

questions.text: An ENT Surgeon while doing singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV has cut its parent nerve accidentally. Which other structure is supposed to lose its sensory supply now, apart from posterior semicircular canal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Macula of saccule

 

Singular nerve is a branch of inferior vestibular nerve. IVN supplies posterior semicircular canal as well as saccule. Sensory structures in the saccule and utricle are macula and those in the semicircular canals are called as cristae.

questions.text: A postnatal day 2 weeks male infant Nanhe presented to his pediatrician Dr Anand with thrombocytopenia. Cardiopulmonary and abdomen examination showed no obvious abnormalities. However, his laboratory results were as follows: white blood cell 9000cells/ul, hemoglbin 15.2 g and platelet count around 50,000/ul. The immune function examination and blood lymphocyte subsets tests were mildly abnormal. The child died from brain bleeding shortly after admission. The family history documented that the infant’s uncle died in infancy due to repeated infections. His mother was physically healthy. A panel of gene mutation studies was performed and a loss of function mutation was detected in one of the genes. Which of the following genes is the most likely mutated in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. WASP

 

The given history is suggestive of Wiskott Aldrich syndrome. So, the answer is WASP gene.

choices.text: Rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol plus dexamethasone

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman is hospitalized with status epilepticus. Family members describe a 6-week history of agitation, delusions, hallucinations, and confusion. She is intubated and over the next 2 days continues to have intermittent seizures despite receiving lorazepam, fosphenytoin, and levetiracetam at maximal doses. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The patient is intubated; she is awake but does not follow commands. Neurologic examination otherwise has no focal abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies show a serum sodium  level of 130 mEq/L (130 mmol/L), and the immunoassay result for the antibody to the leucine-rich glioma inactivated 1 subunit of the voltage-gated potassium channel is positive. Cerebrospinal fluid is normal, including a negative herpes simplex virus polymerase chain reaction result. MRI shows medial temporal lobe hyperintensity. Continuous electroencephalography reveals five seizures in the previous 24 hours, arising independently from both temporal lobes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Immunosuppressive therapy

 

The most appropriate treatment for this patient is immunosuppressive therapy (Option A). This patient has an antibody-mediated neurologic syndrome, which may occur as a primary autoimmune disorder or as a manifestation of a paraneoplastic syndrome. Various syndromes have been described with different neurologic manifestations and findings on serum and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) testing. Findings suggestive of an autoimmune/paraneoplastic neurologic syndrome include new-onset status epilepticus in a patient without epilepsy, acute psychosis in a previously healthy patient, acute movement disorder (ataxia, chorea, myoclonus, tremor), and acute progressive peripheral neuropathy. This patient has electroencephalographic (temporal lobe seizures), imaging (temporal lobe hyperintensity), and serological evidence of anti-leucine-rich glioma inactivated 1 (LGI1) encephalitis. The most prominent findings in anti-LGI1 encephalitis are confusion, psychosis, hyponatremia, and drug-resistant seizures. It is associated with cancer in up to 10% of cases, most commonly thymoma. CSF analysis may be normal or show oligoclonal bands. Treatment options include a combination of high-dose glucocorticoids and either plasma exchange or immunoglobulins, often followed by long-term immunotherapy (e.g., rituximab or cyclophosphamide).

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 is the most common cause of sporadic encephalitis in the United States. CSF usually shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, an elevated protein level, and a normal glucose level. Polymerase chain reaction of the CSF is 98% sensitive and 94% specific in the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis; this patient has normal CSF and a negative PCR test, and acyclovir treatment (Option B) is not indicated.

 

Four-drug antituberculous therapy (rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol) plus dexamethasone (Option C) would be appropriate for the treatment of tuberculous meningitis. Tuberculous meningitis classically presents as basilar meningitis with cranial neuropathies, mental status changes, and the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone resulting in hyponatremia. CSF examination shows a lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein level, and low glucose. These findings are not present, and antituberculosis treatment is not indicated.

 

Aggressive immunosuppressant therapy improves clinical outcomes in up to 80% of patients with anti-LGI1 encephalitis, although relapses are not uncommon. Supportive care alone (Option D) may result in death or severe cognitive impairment and is not the best option for this patient.

choices.text: Steeper Trendelenburg to improve patients’ ventilation
Verres needle insertion at an angle perpendicular to the skin
Placement of additional ports to assist in lifting a fatter abdomen
Use of a gel pad and tucking of patients arms to prevent patient slippage

questions.text: A 49-year woman is undergoing a laparoscopic hysterectomy for adenomyosis. Her BMI is 34. Which is NOT used as a method to compensate for difficulties encountered in laparoscopy in an obese patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Steeper Trendelenburg to improve patients’ ventilation

  • Most laparoscopic pelvic surgeries are done in a Trendelenburg position
  • However, in an obese patient a steep Trendelenburg will lead to more cardio-respiratory compromise
  • All the other options are useful in preventing complications in obese women in laparoscopic gyn surgeries.

choices.text: Immediately after the bifurcation of the common iliac artery
Before the bifurcation of the common iliac artery
3 cm after the bifurcation of the common iliac artery
Just before the posterior division is given off

questions.text: A 23y G2 had atonic PPH during cesarean for placenta previa. A decision for internal iliac artery ligation is taken. What is the best place to ligate the internal iliac artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 cm after the bifurcation of the common iliac artery

  • The internal iliac artery is ligated 3-5cm after the bifurcation of the common iliac artery
  • This is done to ensure only the anterior division is ligated as at this point, the posterior division would have been given off

choices.text: Placement of a left intercostal drain tube in triangle of safety

questions.text: A teenage boy falls from his bicycle and is run over by a car. On arrival in the emergency room (ER), he is awake and alert and appears frightened but in no distress. The chest radiograph suggests an air-fluid level in the left lower lung field and the nasogastric tube seems to coil upward into the left chest. Which of the following is the next best step in his management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laparotomy

 

The patient has an acute diaphragmatic rupture, which occurs in about 4% of patients who sustain either blunt abdominal or chest trauma, and should be treated with immediate laparotomy, which allows both for examination of the intra-abdominal solid and hollow viscera for associated injuries and for adequate exposure of the diaphragm to allow secure repair. Because of the risk of vascular compromise of the contents of the hernia, exacerbated by the negative thoracic pressure, acute diaphragmatic rupture should be repaired immediately. Diagnosis may be difficult. The finding of an air-fluid level in the left lower chest, with a nasogastric tube entering it after blunt trauma to the abdomen, is diagnostic of diaphragmatic rupture with gastric herniation into the chest. eFAST, CT scanning and MRI may be useful adjuncts, but neither can definitively rule out diaphragmatic rupture. Diaphragmatic repair can be accomplished via the left chest, but laparotomy is the procedure of choice for acute traumatic rupture for the stated reasons.

questions.text: A 15 years old child with mental age 5 years will be classified as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Imbecile with Severe mental retardation

 

Levels of Intelligence based on IQ levels:

  • Idiot 0 – 24
  • Imbecile 25 – 49
  • Moron 50 – 69
  • Borderline 70 – 79
  • Low normal 80 – 89
  • Normal 90 – 109
  • Superior 110 – 119
  • Very superior 120 – 139
  • Near Genius 140 and over

Categories of mental retardation based on IQ levels:

  • Normal IQ: 70 and over
  • Mild mental retardation: 50 – 69
  • Moderate mental retardation: 35 – 49
  • Severe mental retardation: 21 – 34
  • Profound mental retardation: 20 or below

In the given question, IQ level of this child is Mental age/Chronological age X 100 = 5/15 X 100 = 33 IQ points

So, he’s an Imbecile with Severe mental retardation

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after Iying on the floor in her home for the past 2 days. The patient's neighbor called police after phone calls were not answered and no one opened the door. She was found awake on the bathroom floor lying in feces and urine. The patient says she fell and injured her right hip and was unable to get up to call for help. She did not eat or drink anything during that time. On examination the patient appears dehydrated and has right hip tenderness. Laboratory studies show serum glucose of 72 mg/dL and positive urine ketones. Radiographs of the right hip show a right femoral neck fracture. Increased activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely contributing to both the serum and urine laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hormone-sensitive lipase

 

This patient's laboratory studies show the presence of ketones in the urine and maintenance of fasting blood glucose values in the low-normal range despite prolonged fasting. Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is an enzyme found in adipose tissue that catalyzes the mobilization of stored triglycerides into free fatty acids (FFAs) and glycerol. HSL is activated in response to stress hormones (eg, catecholamines, glucagon, ACTH), whereas it is inhibited by the release of insulin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the orthopaedic clinic with complaints of shoulder pain and weakness in his right arm for the past several weeks. He reports that the pain is most severe when he tries to lift objects or reach overhead. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the anterior aspect of the shoulder, and the patient demonstrates weakness in flexing his right arm against resistance. Which structure is having highest probability to affect in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C

  • In this case tenderness in the anterior aspect of the shoulder, and weakness in flexing arm against resistance indicates problem in biceps muscle. Clinically long head of biceps is involved.
  • Long head of biceps arises from supra glenoid tubercle. Which is indicated as C in this image.

 

 

In given shoulder joint image:

A- Deltoid

B- Coracoacromian ligament

C- Long head of biceps

D- Short head of biceps

questions.text: As a of a research study investigating enzymatic activity in both normal and diseased liver tissue, hepatocytes are isolated from biopsy samples obtained from patients undergoing routine care at a local tertiary referral center. The cells are homogenized and centrifuged to remove membrane components and organelles. Following subsequent rounds of centrifugation, the remaining supernatant contains only cytosol and cytosolic proteins. Activity of which of the following enzymes will most likely be detectable in the supernatant of healthy liver cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Transketolase

 

Exp: Cellular compartmentalization provides a means by which multiple heterogeneous environments can exist within a cell.  Mitochondria are the site of beta-oxidation of fatty acids, the citric acid cycle, and the carboxylation of pyruvate (gluconeogenesis) The cytosol is home to enzymes necessary for glycolysis, fatty acid synthesis, and the pentose phosphate pathway. Transketolase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway that uses thiamine (vitamin B,) as a cofactor to shuttle 2-carbon fragments between sugar molecules. Other processes such as heme synthesis, the urea cycle, and gluconeogenesis rely on a complex interplay between the mitochondria and cytosol to function optimally.

questions.text: 1-day-old boy is diagnosed with hyperphenylalanemia by newborn screening. He is placed on a special phenylalanine-restricted diet with tyrosine supplementation. The parents are extensively counselled on the boy's condition and informed of the necessary dietary restrictions. They are also instructed to return to his physician for regular follow-up visits. Several months later, laboratory test results indicate that the infant has a normal serum phenylalanine level. Careful examination, however, reveals some neurological abnormalities, including axial hypotonia and microcephaly. Further workup is notable for elevated prolactin. What is the likely deficiency leading to this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dihydrobiopterin reductase

 

Exp: Disorders involving impaired tetrahydrobiopterin (BH.) levels, the most common being dihydrobiopterin reductase deficiency, account for 2% of phenyiketonuria cases. BH4 is an important cofactor for both phenylalanine hydroxylase and tyrosine hydroxylase. Although phenylalanine levels can be corrected with dietary restriction, downstream deficiencies of dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, and serotonin lead to progressive neurologic deterioration. Dopamine deficiency leads to hyperprolactinemia in these patients.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man is evaluated during a follow-up visit after a recent hospitalization for new-onset heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. He initially presented with progressive shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. His symptoms were relieved by diuretic therapy and empagliflozin. ECG revealed normal sinus rhythm with low voltage. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a thickened left ventricular wall and an ejection fraction of 58%. Medical history includes COPD, hypertension, carpal tunnel syndrome, osteoarthritis, and localized prostate cancer. Medications include candesartan, empagliflozin, acetaminophen, torsemide, and tiotropium. On today's physical examination, blood pressure is 132/74 mm Hg, pulse rate is 82/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% with the patient breathing room air. There is no jugular venous distention, and the lung fields are clear. Cardiac examination reveals no murmur or extra heart sounds. There is no lower extremity edema. Results of serum and urine protein electrophoresis with immunofixation and free light-chain assay are normal. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging shows late gadolinium enhancement, suggesting amyloidosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 99m-Technetium pyrophosphate scintigraphy

 

The most appropriate next step in this patient with likely cardiac amyloidosis is to perform 99m-technetium pyrophosphate scintigraphy (Option D). The diagnosis of cardiac amyloidosis is suggested by the combination of low voltage on the ECG and left ventricular hypertrophy on transthoracic echocardiography. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging is the most appropriate test in patients with suspected cardiac amyloidosis. Although CMR is highly sensitive and specific for cardiac amyloidosis, it cannot differentiate between the two major forms of disease: light-chain amyloid (AL) amyloidosis and transthyretin amyloid (ATTR) amyloidosis. Differentiation between these causes is crucial because treatment and prognosis differ significantly. This patient has no evidence of an underlying monoclonal disorder to implicate AL amyloidosis, as demonstrated by the normal serum and urine electrophoresis with immunofixation and light chain assay results. 99m-Technetium pyrophosphate scintigraphy has excellent sensitivity and specificity for ATTR amyloidosis and is the next best test to assess the likelihood of this disease.

 

Cardiac catheterization (Option A) may be indicated in patients with heart failure in whom there is a high suspicion of coronary artery disease (CAD) as the underlying cause. This patient's clinical presentation does not suggest CAD; therefore, cardiac catheterization is not indicated.

 

Endomyocardial biopsy (Option B) is an important diagnostic test for patients with suspected myocarditis, giant cell myocarditis, and other infiltrative cardiomyopathies. For evaluating suspected cardiac amyloidosis, however, the utility of noninvasive testing techniques such as CMR and 99m-technetium pyrophosphate scintigraphy has obviated the need for endomyocardial biopsy in most patients

 

Tafamidis (Option C), a protein stabilizer, is an FDA-approved, guideline-recommended therapy that reduces mortality and cardiovascular hospitalization in patients with ATTR cardiac amyloidosis. Although tafamidis is a key therapy in patients with ATTR disease, initiating therapy before establishing the diagnosis would be premature.

questions.text: A series of experiments are being conducted to determine the structure and function of different types of bacterial RNA. Cultures of Staphylococcus aureus are exposed to chemicals that lyse the bacterial cells, and the RNA molecules are then extracted. A specific RNA consisting of 90 nucleotides is purified for further analysis. It is found to contain high amounts of chemically modified bases such as dithydrouridine, pseudouridine, and its secondary structure arises from base pairing within the chain. Which of the following is the most likely composition of the 3'-end of this molecule?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CCA

 

Exp: Transfer RNA (tRNA) is a small, noncoding form of RNA that contains chemically modified bases (eg, dihydrouridine, ribothymidine, pseudouridine). RNA has a CCA sequence at its 3'-end that is used as a recognition sequence by proteins. The 3' terminal hydroxyl group of the CCA tail serves as the amino acid binding site.

choices.text: Insertion of abnormal bases into DNA

questions.text: 34-year-old woman comes to the physician with abdominal pain and melena. She also complains of progressive fatigue and a 5 kg weight loss over the last 2 months. She has a strong family history of colon, endometrial, and ovarian cancer. Colonoscopy shows a protuberant, friable mass in the ascending colon, and biopsy is diagnostic for colon adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation consistent with Lynch syndrome. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the development of colon cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nucleotide mismatches that escape repair

 

Exp: Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease caused by abnormal nucleotide mismatch repair. The mismatch repair system involves several genes, including MSH2 and MLH1, which code for components of the human MutS and Mutl homologs. Mutations in these 2 genes account for around 90% of cases of Lynch syndrome.

choices.text: IV Unfractionated Heparin followed by Warfarin

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for shortness of breath and chest discomfort of 2 days' duration. She has stage IV pancreatic cancer and recently completed a cycle of gemcitabine-based chemotherapy. Medical history is also relevant for hypertension, dyslipidemia, and hypothyroidism. Medications are lisinopril, atorvastatin, and levothyroxine. On physical examination, blood pressure is 144/76 mm Hg and pulse rate is 95/min. Oxygen saturation  is 95% breathing ambient air. The examination is normal. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL (79.6 µmol/L); serum troponin and B-type natriuretic peptide levels are normal. CT scan of the chest shows several segmental pulmonary emboli without right ventricular dilation. An electrocardiogram is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Apixaban

 

This patient should be treated with apixaban (Option A). The 2021 American Society of Hematology (ASH) and 2021 American College of Chest Physicians (CHEST) guidelines recommend initial anticoagulation with a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) in patients with malignancy and acute venous thromboembolism (VTE). The ASH guidelines suggest low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) as immediate initial therapy but state that apixaban, rivaroxaban, and edoxaban are preferred to LMWH for the subsequent 3 to 6 months of anticoagulation. The CHEST guidelines also state that apixaban or LMWH may be preferred in patients with luminal gastrointestinal malignancies because of a lower risk of gastrointestinal bleeding with these agents. In this patient with pancreatic cancer–associated pulmonary emboli and normal kidney function, treatment with a DOAC such as apixaban is indicated.

 

Inferior vena cava (IVC) filter placement is indicated in patients with acute VTE and a contraindication to anticoagulation (Option B). However, IVC filters increase the risk of deep venous thrombosis and should not be used as primary therapy in patients who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation.

 

Intravenous unfractionated heparin followed by warfarin is a second-line option in most patients with acute VTE (Option C). It is most appropriate in patients with a contraindication to DOACs and LMWH therapy, such as severe kidney disease. Guidelines do not recommend the use of warfarin as first-line therapy in patients with malignancy-associated VTE.

 

Thrombolytic therapy with intravenous tenecteplase is indicated in patients with acute pulmonary embolism (PE) associated with hypotension (Option D). Guidelines differ regarding use of thrombolytic therapy in patients with acute PE at high risk for decompensation or submassive pulmonary embolism. This patient does not have hypotension or high-risk factors, such as elevated biomarkers (troponin, B-type natriuretic peptide) and right ventricular dysfunction, so thrombolytic therapy is not indicated.

questions.text:
31-year-old woman comes to the office due to transient visual changes that are characterized by "loss of vision for a minute" and are commonly precipitated by bending forward or lifting objects. She has had persistent headaches over the last 3 months that she attributes to migraines. The patient takes over-the-counter analgesics as needed. Blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min and regular. BMI is 32.4 kg/m². Funduscopic examination of both eyes reveals the findings shown in the image below.

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of the observed funduscopic findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Impaired optic nerve axoplasmic flow

 

This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri). This condition typically presents in young obese women with daily headache, bilateraly symmetric paplledema, and transient visual disturbances related to impaired cerebral venous outflow and elevated intracranial pressure. Symptoms characteristically worsen during Valsalva (eg, bending down, coughing) as intracranial pressure increases.  Increased intracranial pressure is transmitted through the cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space, which is continuous with the optic nerve sheath. This buildup of pressure compresses the optic nerves externally, which in tum impairs axoplasmic flow within the optic nerves, causing bilateral optic disc edema (papilledema). Compared to normal funduscopy, patients with papilledema have elevation of the optic disc with blurred disc margins.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of skin tightness and sclerotic plaques on the lower trunk and left thigh. The plaques began with redness and induration. The skin tightness limits motion of the trunk. She reports no heartburn, Raynaud phenomenon, joint pain, or swelling. She has no other medical conditions and takes no medications. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There are indurated and sclerotic plaques on the trunk and one plaque on the left thigh, as shown. There is no sclerodactyly or telangiectasias.

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Morphea

 

The most likely diagnosis is morphea (Option A). Morphea, a type of localized scleroderma, is an inflammatory disorder of unknown cause that leads to sclerotic changes in the skin. This patient has a classic presentation for morphea. Morphea typically occurs in plaques on the trunk in particular, the extremities, and occasionally the face. As the lesions age, they transition from red and indurated to thickened and sclerotic, often with a yellow/white coloration, to atrophic skin lesions with peripheral hyperpigmentation combined with central sclerosis. Therapy in morphea depends on the extent and depth of involvement. An isolated plaque limited to the dermis is treated with topical or injected glucocorticoids or tacrolimus ointment. For more generalized dermal involvement, phototherapy is recommended. For patients with deeper involvement (below the dermis layer of skin), methotrexate is the drug of choice, with intravenous methylprednisolone added for rapidly progressive cases.

 

Scleredema (Option B) is typically seen in patients with diabetes mellitus and causes thickened, indurated skin over the neck and shoulder girdle that can limit range of motion. In this patient, the absence of diabetes and location of the lesions on the trunk and thigh argue against scleredema.

 

Scleromyxedema (Option C) is characterized by waxy, yellow-red papules over thickened skin of the face, upper trunk, neck, and arms. Scleromyxedema is associated with paraproteinemia and may therefore occur in the setting of multiple myeloma or AL amyloidosis. This patient's sclerotic skin lesions on the lower trunk and thigh are not compatible with scleromyxedema.

 

Clinical features that help distinguish between systemic sclerosis (Option D) and morphea are the lack of Raynaud phenomenon, absence of mat-like telangiectasias on the hands and face, and lack of internal organ involvement in morphea compared with systemic sclerosis. Raynaud phenomenon is present in up to 95% of systemic sclerosis cases; if it is absent, another diagnosis should be considered. In addition, a negative antinuclear antibody (ANA) result argues against systemic sclerosis because ANA findings are positive in 94% of patients with systemic sclerosis. The ANA result is positive in a minority of patients with morphea (up to 30%).

choices.text: Conductive loss in left ear
Conductive loss in right ear
Sensorineural loss in left ear
Sensorineural loss in right ear

questions.text: 54-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to difficulty hearing for the past few weeks. During the neurologic examination, the physician assesses her hearing using a vibrating tuning fork. The handle of the tuning fork is placed on her left mastoid process until the sound is no longer audible. The tines are then quickly placed near the patient's left auditory meatus, and she reports hearing no sound. When the handle of the vibrating fork is placed on the middle of her forehead, she hears the vibration more strongly in her left ear than her right. This patient is most likely experiencing which of the following types of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Conductive loss in left ear

 

In conductive hearing loss, bone conduction will be. greater than air conduction (abnormal Rinne test), and the Weber test will lateralize to the affected ear. In sensorineural hearing loss, air conduction will be greater than bone conduction (normal Rinne test), and the Weber test will lateralize to the unaffected ear.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of abdominal distension in this 55-year-old male?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Malignancy

 

Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to a syndrome of progressive intraperitoneal accumulation of mucinous ascites related to a mucin-producing neoplasm. It is most commonly caused by a mucinous tumour of the appendix. Much less commonly, mucinous tumours of the colon, rectum, stomach, pancreas, and urachus are implicated. CT shows simple or loculated low attenuation fluid throughout intraperitoneal spaces, omentum, and mesentery with scalloping of visceral surfaces, particularly the liver.

questions.text: An infant is born with facial dysmorphia and a cleft palate. Further evaluation reveals a heart condition with a right-to-left shunt and the absence of a thymic shadow on x-ray. The infant experiences frequent and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. Examination of this patient's lymph nodes will most likely show poor development of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Paracortex region

 

DiGeorge syndrome is caused by maldevelopment of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouch derivatives. Immunodeficiency can result from thymic aplasia, which leads to an extreme deficiency in the number of mature T Iymphocytes. Although T cells are synthesized in the bone marrow, they require processing in the thymus in order to mature and mount effective immune responses. Patients are thus predisposed to recurrent infections by viral, fungal, protozoan, and intracellular bacterial pathogens.

 

DiGeorge syndrome causes an extreme deficiency in the number of mature T lymphocytes, leading to poor development of the lymph node paracortex. In contrast, agammaglobulinemia causes an absence of B cells, preventing primary lymphoid follicles and germinal centers from forming in the lymph node cortex.

questions.text: A 22-year-old previously healthy male presents to the emergency department with a five-day history of worsening symptoms. He initially complained of a sore throat and fever, which were managed with over-the-counter pain relievers. However, he now reports increasing difficulty swallowing and neck pain. On examination, the patient appears unwell, with a high fever (39.5°C or 103.1°F) and pronounced tenderness over the left side of his neck. His throat examination reveals severe pharyngitis with a swollen and erythematous uvula. Laboratory findings show leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck and chest is shown here. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lemierre’s disease

 

This clinical scenario is suggestive of Lemierre's syndrome, a rare but serious condition that typically begins with a sore throat and then progresses to more severe symptoms. The key features that point towards Lemierre's syndrome in this case include the prolonged duration of symptoms, high fever, swollen and tender cervical lymph nodes, and difficulty moving the neck due to pain. It is often associated with a recent throat infection that is negative for streptococcal pharyngitis, as Lemierre's syndrome is usually caused by anaerobic bacteria, primarily Fusobacterium necrophorum. Early recognition and treatment with antibiotics and sometimes surgical drainage are essential to manage this condition.

questions.text: 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to excessive urination and thirst. He has lost 4.5 kg (10 lb) in the last 3 weeks. The patient has no past medical problems. His father has type 1 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Laboratory studies reveal blood glucose of 455 mg/dlL, normal anion gap, and hemoglobin A1c of 11.3%. The patient is diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, and treatment with insulin is initiated. ln addition to lowering blood glucose, insulin increases glycogen synthesis in hepatocytes. Activation of which of the following molecules most likely promotes this metabolic effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Protein phosphatase

 

The surface receptor for insulin is a transmembrane protein with intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity in its cytoplasmic domain. Insulin binding activates tyrosine kinase, leading to phosphorylation of insulin receptor substrate 1 (IRS-1). IRS-1 then activates several intracellular pathways that induce the physiologic effects of insulin. Activation of the MAP kinase pathway promotes mitogenic functions such as DNA synthesis and cell growth. In contrast, activation of phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase (PI3K) stimulates metabolic functions such as translocation of GLUT-4 to the cell membrane, glycogen synthesis, and fat synthesis. Pl3K promotes glycogen synthesis by activating protein phosphatase, an enzyme that dephosphorylates glycogen synthase, leading to its activation.

choices.text: Extensive double-strand DNA break repair

questions.text: 24-year-old woman comes to the office after discovering a new mole on her right leg. She is worried that it might be skin cancer as she has been going out in the sun very frequently because of her job as a reporter. Physical examination shows a 5-mm brown, oval macule on her anterior thigh with a homogeneous coloration and discrete borders. The lesion appears darker than her other moles. A biopsy of the lesion shows normal-appearing nevus cells clustered in the epidermis, and she is diagnosed with a benign acquired melanocytic nevus. During histologic analysis, her epithelial cells are each found to contain a condensed body composed of heavily methylated DNA at the periphery of the nucleus. This region of DNA is most likely associated with which of the following genetic findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Low transcription activity

 

X-inactivation occurs in genetically normal females and results in conversion of the inactivated X chromosome into compact heterochromatin (Barr body). Heterochromatin is condensed chromatin composed of heavily methylated DNA in tight association with deacetylated histones. It has a low level of transcriptional activity. In contrast, euchromatin is loosely arranged and exhibits a high level of transcriptional activity.

questions.text: 6-year-old boy is brought to the office due to a persistent facial ulcer for the past 2 months. His mother reports that the patient has extreme sensitivity to sunlight and has developed freckles on his face, neck, and limbs since infancy. On physical examination, the skin in sun-exposed areas is dry and rough with numerous freckles and erythematous macules. There is an ulcerated plaque on the left face; a biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma. Further testing leads to a diagnosis of xeroderma pigmentosum. A defect in which of the following enzymes is most likely causing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endonuclease

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by defective nucleotide excision repair often caused by a deficiency in UV-specific endonuclease. Affected children usually have severe photosensitivity, hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas, and a greatly increased risk for skin cancer.

Ans. D. All of the above
