questions.text: A 66-year-old man undergoes a low anterior resection for rectal adenocarcinoma. On the fifth day in hospital, his physical examination shows a temperature of 39°C (102°F), blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg, pulse of 110 beats per minute and regular, and respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen reveals an abscess in the pelvis. Which of the following most accurately describes his present condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sepsis

 

The correct diagnosis is sepsis. Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) involves 2 or more of the following: temperature >38°C (100°F) , HR more than 90 beats per minute, respiratory rate >20 or WBC more than 12,000 or 10% immature neutrophils.

Sepsis = SIRS + documented infection.

Severe sepsis = sepsis + organ dysfunction or hypoperfusion (lactic acidosis, oliguria, or altered mental status).

Septic shock = sepsis + organ dysfunction + hypotension (systolic blood pressure 90 mm Hg with vasopressors).

choices.text: A cholesterol containing tumour in the middle ear
Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative
Endodermal derivative in a space enclosed by ectodermal derivative
Mesodermal tissue proliferation in middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following description best fits cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative

 

Squamous epithelial lining (ectodermal derivative) in the external ear canal and outer layer of tympanic membrane should lie outside to the middle fibrous layer (mesodermal) of tympanic membrane. Inside to the middle fibrous layer of tympanic membrane, mucosal lining (endodermal) will be there as inner layer of tympanic membrane as well as mucosal lining of entire cavity of middle ear.

 

Cholesteatoma means the presence of squamous epithelium in the middle ear i.e., ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by the endodermal derivative.

questions.text: 63-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine preventive examination. She has no significant medical problems and takes no medications. The patient consumes a balanced diet; gets regular exercise; and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or ilicit drugs. She is up to date on breast, colon, cervical, and lipid screenings. Her physical examination findings are unremarkable. The patient expresses concern about wrinkles around her eyes that make her "look old." A decrease in which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's complaint?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Collagen fibril production

 

Exp: Photoaging is a product of excess exposure to ultraviolet A wavelengths and is characterized by epidermal atrophy with flattening of rete ridges. In addition, there is decreased collagen fibril production and increased degradation of collagen and elastin in the dermis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the paediatrician by her parents due to a rapidly spreading skin rash. On examination, there are widespread areas of erythema with large areas of skin exfoliation as shown below. The parents report that the child had a recent episode of sore throat for which they did not seek medical attention. On further workup, cultures from the skin lesions grow Staphylococcus aureus. The pathogenesis of this child's skin condition is most similar to which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pemphigus foliaceous

 

The child in the scenario is suffering from a staphylococcal skin infection that is causing exfoliative dermatitis, also known as Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). The toxin-mediated condition results in widespread erythema and skin exfoliation due to cleavage of desmoglein 1, which holds keratinocytes together in the superficial skin layers. 

 

The pathogenesis of this condition—specifically, the cleavage of desmoglein 1—is most similar to the mechanism seen in: C. Pemphigus foliaceous.

choices.text: Hepatic metastasis of melanoma.

questions.text: Dr. Amrit Nasta is consulted regarding a 56-year-old patient, Alok, who has been diagnosed with metastatic melanoma. Alok's pathology report indicates a high expression of PD-L1 in tumor cells. After previously showing resistance to the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib, Dr. Nasta decides to administer pembrolizumab, an immune checkpoint inhibitor, hoping to harness Alok's immune system against the tumor. A week into treatment with pembrolizumab, Alok presents with fatigue, joint pain, a mild rash, and an elevation of liver enzymes in his blood tests. What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Autoimmune hepatitis.

 

  1. Hepatic metastasis of melanoma: While metastatic melanoma can spread to the liver and cause an elevation in liver enzymes, it is less likely to account for the combination of fatigue, joint pain, rash, and elevated liver enzymes shortly after starting pembrolizumab.
  2. Autoimmune hepatitis: This is the most likely cause given the context. Immune checkpoint inhibitors, like pembrolizumab, unleash the immune system to attack tumors but can also lead to it attacking normal organs, causing autoimmune conditions. The combination of symptoms Alok is experiencing – fatigue, joint pain, rash, and elevated liver enzymes – is consistent with a diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis triggered by pembrolizumab.
  3. Pembrolizumab-induced direct hepatotoxicity: As of the current understanding, the primary hepatotoxic effects of immune checkpoint inhibitors like pembrolizumab are immune-mediated. While these drugs can lead to liver enzyme elevations, they typically do so by provoking an autoimmune response, rather than through direct hepatocyte damage.
  4. Viral hepatitis reactivation: Some drugs can reactivate chronic viral hepatitis (like hepatitis B or C). While it's a consideration in patients with a history or risk of viral hepatitis who present with liver enzyme elevations, there's nothing in the vignette to suggest that Alok has a history or risk of chronic viral hepatitis. Moreover, the constellation of symptoms is more consistent with autoimmune effects than viral reactivation.
    Given the clinical presentation and timing after initiating therapy with pembrolizumab, the symptoms are most consistent with autoimmune hepatitis, an immune-related adverse event associated with the use of immune checkpoint inhibitors.

questions.text: In which of the following study designs, the Outcome of interest has already taken place when the study is started?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Retrospective cohort study

  • In a Prospective cohort study, Outcome has not yet occurred when the study has begun: Only exposure has occurred; we look for development of same disease in both exposed and non-exposed groups
  • In a Retrospective cohort study, both exposure as well as outcome have occurred when the study has begun: First we go back in time and take only exposure into consideration (cohorts identified from past hospital/college records), then look for development of same disease in both exposed and non-exposed groups
  • In a nested case control study, only exposure has occurred when the study begins; when the disease develops in a population later in time, then 2 groups of cases (diseased) and controls (non-diseased) are formed and their exposure status is compared.

choices.text: The iron lung uses positive pressure to assist with inhalation and exhalation, enhancing oxygenation and CO2 removal.
The iron lung relies on negative pressure to create a vacuum around the patient's chest, promoting lung expansion and gas exchange.
The iron lung is equipped with advanced ventilator algorithms and real-time monitoring to adjust ventilation parameters automatically.
The iron lung stimulates the phrenic nerve through electrical impulses, restoring normal diaphragmatic function.

questions.text: An elderly patient is admitted to the hospital with a severe case of polio that has affected their respiratory muscles. Despite maximal medical therapy, the patient is experiencing significant respiratory distress and requires mechanical ventilation. Due to the patient's unique needs, the medical team decides to use an iron lung for respiratory support. Which of the following best describes the functioning principle of above given support system and its application in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The iron lung relies on negative pressure to create a vacuum around the patient's chest, promoting lung expansion and gas exchange.

 

An iron lung, also known as a negative pressure ventilator, is a device used to assist patients with respiratory paralysis, such as those affected by polio.

 

It works by enclosing the patient's body from the neck down within a large airtight chamber. The chamber is then alternately pressurized and depressurized, creating a negative pressure around the chest and abdomen.

 

During negative pressure cycles, the chest expands, leading to inhalation, while relaxation of the chamber causes exhalation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is undergoing spinal surgery for the correction of severe thoracic kyphosis. The surgical team is particularly concerned about potential damage to the spinal cord during the procedure. In order to continuously assess the integrity of specific neural pathways, the anaesthesiologist and neurologist decide to use intraoperative monitoring. Which of the following intraoperative monitoring techniques provides real-time information about the functional status of motor pathways, and is most appropriate for detecting early signs of spinal cord ischemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Motor evoked potentials (MEPs)


Motor evoked potentials (MEPs) provide real-time feedback about the functional integrity of motor pathways. They are especially valuable in surgeries where there's a risk to the spinal cord or motor cortex. While SSEPs can be used to monitor the integrity of sensory pathways, they are not as sensitive as MEPs in detecting anterior spinal cord ischemia, which affects the motor pathways. EEG primarily monitors cerebral electrical activity and is not specific for spinal cord function. EMG monitors muscle activity and can detect nerve root irritation, but it doesn't provide the real-time feedback on motor pathway function like MEPs.

choices.text: Hepatitis B surface antigen and hepatitis B core antibody testing in 6 months

questions.text: A 35-year-old doctor is evaluated for a needlestick injury that occurred earlier in the day while she was at work. She received the hepatitis B vaccination series 5 years ago and checked her anti-HBS titer which was > 10 mU/mL. The source patient has known active hepatitis B infection. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Apart from a tiny puncture wound at the site of injury, the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's hepatitis B exposure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. No further management

 

This patient, who was exposed to hepatitis B virus (HBV) and is a known vaccine responder, requires no further management (Option D). Pre-exposure prophylaxis through hepatitis B vaccination is recommended for all healthcare personnel and is effective in preventing HBV infection. This patient has received the hepatitis B vaccine series, and her antibody to hepatitis B surface antigen (anti-HBs) is greater than 10 mU/mL, indicating that she had a favorable immunologic response. Therefore, it is highly unlikely that she would become infected with HBV as a result of her recent exposure, and no further management is needed.

 

Hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG) (Option A) is not indicated in this patient who is a known hepatitis B vaccine responder. HBIG is indicated if the source patient is positive for HBV and the healthcare worker is a vaccine nonresponder (anti-HBs <10 mU/mL), is unvaccinated, or is incompletely vaccinated. When HBIG is indicated, it should be administered as soon as possible after exposure and ideally within 7 days.

 

Repeat hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and hepatitis B core antibody (anti-HBc) testing in 6 months (Option B) is indicated for persons who have been exposed to HBV and are vaccine nonresponders, are unvaccinated, or are incompletely vaccinated. For these patients, testing is indicated at baseline and again at 6 months to assess for the presence of HBV infection.

 

Repeating the hepatitis B vaccination series (Option C) is unnecessary for this patient. She was previously immunized, and her anti-HBs level (>10 mU/mL) indicates that she responded adequately to the vaccine series. Therefore, she does not require revaccination. Revaccination is indicated for vaccine nonresponders. In addition, those who are unvaccinated should be counseled to receive the hepatitis B vaccination series; those who are incompletely vaccinated should be advised to complete the series.

questions.text: A Pregnant woman in third trimester complains of hearing her own sounds. Examination of the ear shows movements of tympanic membrane synchronous with respiration and especially exaggerated when nostril on the contralateral side is occluded. Your diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Patulous Eustachian tube

 

Eustachian tube lies closed most of the time. Opens during yawning, swallowing, chewing, etc., with the help of muscles like tensor veli palatini, levator veli palatini and salpingopharyngeus.

 

Instead, if Eustachian tube stays constantly open, then that condition is called as patulous Eustachian tube. Here, the patient will hear his own voice (autophony), his own breath sounds. On otoscopy, tympanic membrane movements can be seen synchronised with inspiration (inward) and expiration (outward). Few causes include rapid weight loss, 3rd trimester of pregnancy, multiple sclerosis. No treatment required for acute cases. Weight gain, oral KI can be given. Cauterisation of ET or grommet insertion can be planned in chronic cases.

choices.text: A special fetal echocardiographic assessment should be done routinely in MCDA twin pregnancies
MCDA twins are 1% of all pregnancies
MCDA twins has a 15% chance of developing twin to twin transfusion syndrome
She may require an extra scan at around 15 weeks as chorionicity is best established after 14 weeks.

questions.text: A woman has just had her dating ultrasound scan done. The sonographer has clearly documented two gestational sacs (T-sign) and conformed 10 weeks MCDA viable twins. The woman asks you for further information about MCDA twins. Which of the following statements will you quote in your counselling?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MCDA twins has a 15% chance of developing twin to twin transfusion syndrome

  • TTTS complicates up to 15% of monochorionic pregnancies, the placentas have a predominance of unidirectional artery–vein anastomoses. This may lead to a haemodynamic imbalance within the circulations of the twins, directly adversely affecting fetal cardiac function, fetoplacental perfusion and fetal renal function.
  • Chorionicity should be determined at the time the twin pregnancy is detected by ultrasound based upon the number of placental masses, the appearance of the membrane attachment to the placenta and the membrane thickness. This scan is best performed before 14 weeks of gestation.
  • MCDA twins account for about 1/3rd of all monozygotic twins
  • MCMA twins account for about 1% of all twins
  • A detailed fetal anomaly scan should be done between 19-20 weeks but a routine fetal echocardiography for all MCDA twins is NOT recommended.

choices.text: VZIG will not be effective this late after exposure
Treat as infectious up to 28 days
Check for features of fetal varicella syndrome on 20 weeks scan

questions.text: A 26y old primigravida who is also a school teacher, was exposed to chicken pox 7 days ago. She is currently 19 weeks pregnant. She does not remember getting a chickenpox rash in childhood. Serum testing for varicella was done and was found to be non-immune to varicella. What is the single best advice for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. VZIG should be administered

There are 2 important aspects to chicken pox in pregnancy:

  • Pregnant patient presents with rash (Chicken pox)
  • Pregnant patient presents with contact with a person who has chicken pox, and is therefore at risk of developing chicken pox

Scenario 1: Pregnant patient with rash i.e. she has already developed chicken pox

  • Avoid contact with susceptible individuals, until the lesions have crusted over. This is usually about 5 days after the onset of the rash.
  • Symptomatic treatment and hygiene is advised to prevent secondary bacterial infection of the lesions.
  • Oral Acyclovir should be prescribed
  • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has developed.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist, at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection, for discussion and detailed ultrasound examination (Risk of congenital varicella)
  • If maternal infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of a woman’s pregnancy, there is a significant risk of varicella infection of the newborn. A planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.
     

Scenario 2: Pregnant patient with history of contact with a person who has chicken pox

  • Determine if she has been vaccinated against chicken pox or has had the infection earlier (i.e. immunized)
  • IF immunized, nothing further need be done
  • If not sure of status: Do IgG VZV
  • If IgG VZV is positive: she is immunized and nothing need be done
  • If she is IgG VZV negative or she is unimmunized: This means she is susceptible and should be given VZ IG within 10 days of contact.

 

 

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg13.pdf

questions.text: If the plasma concentration of a freely filterable substance is 2 mg/mL, GFR is 100 mL/min, urine concentration of the substance is 10 mg/mL, and urine flow rate is 5 mL/min, we can conclude that the kidney tubules:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Reabsorbed 150 mg/min

 

According to the principle of conservation of mass for a freely filterable substance in the renal system:

Filtered Load α  Excretion Rate

Filtered Load = GFR × Plasma Concentration

Excretion Rate = Urine Flow Rate × Urine Concentration

 

Plasma concentration of the substance = 2 mg/mL

GFR (glomerular filtration rate) = 100 mL/min

Urine concentration of the substance = 10 mg/mL

Urine flow rate = 5 mL/min

Filtered Load = GFR × Plasma Concentration

Filtered Load = 100 mL/min × 2 mg/mL = 200 mg/min

 

Excretion Rate = Urine Flow Rate × Urine Concentration

Excretion Rate = 5 mL/min × 10 mg/mL = 50 mg/min

 

According to the principle of conservation of mass, the filtered load of a substance should equal its excretion rate. In this case, the filtered load is 200 mg/min, and the excretion rate is 50 mg/min.

 

Therefore, the remaining 200 mg/min - 50 mg/min = 150 mg/min must be reabsorbed by the kidney tubules.

choices.text: A - dorsal root ganglion, B – dorsal root of spinal nerve, C – notochord, D – trunk of spinal nerve.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to her obstetrician for a routine prenatal check-up during her first trimester of pregnancy. The obstetrician explains that during the early 6th week of embryonic life, significant developmental events occur in the cervical region of the spinal cord. (Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Page- 241)

 

  • In given section of spinal cord

  • Notochord disappears in adult body. Its remnant is Nucleus pulposus Q which is found within intervertebral disc.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought in to the physician’s office with a 3-day history of fever and a rash. He has also had a mild sore throat and felt somewhat fatigued. His mother is concerned that he could have “scarlet fever.” The rash started on his face and then spread to his arms and legs. He has only been given acetaminophen for the fever. He takes no other medications, has no known allergies, has no significant medical history, and has had no contact with anyone known to be ill. On examination, his temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), and his other vital signs are normal. His cheeks are notably red, almost as if they had been slapped. His pharynx is normal appearing, and the remainder of his head and neck exam is normal. On his extremities there is a fine, erythematous, maculopapular rash but no vesicles or petechiae. A rapid group A streptococcal antigen test done in the office is negative. Identify the organism likely cause of this illness and tell in which human cells does this virus cause lytic infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Erythroid precursor cells

 

Parvovirus B19 binds with P antigen of immature erythroid progenitor cells of bone marrow causing aplastic crises.

questions.text: In each scenario, choose the best plan for management:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1b, 2a, 3d, 4c

  • Scenario 1 is Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy; Treatment is Induction of labor as she has crossed 37 weeks
  • Scenario 2 is most likely viral hepatitis; treatment is conservative management
  • Scenario 3 is HELLP syndrome, treatment is MgSO4 and cesarean is preferred as there is severe FGR with reversal of diastolic flow
  • Scenario 4 is likely Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy, Treatment is immediate delivery, here emergency LSCS is preferred as there is severe oligohydramnios

choices.text: Time required to reach the steady-state concentration

questions.text: Dr. Sparsh Gupta is conducting a clinical study involving a 30-year-old participant named Kunal. They are examining a novel, pharmacologically inert substance called Y to study its elimination kinetics. Previous trials have shown that Y follows first order kinetics and has the plasma half-life of 1 hour. During the initial stage of the clinical trial, Kunal receives an intravenous administration of Y at a concentration of 20 mg/mL, infused at a constant rate of 2 mL/min for 12 hours. After ensuring that Y has been completely eliminated from Kunal's system, Dr. Gupta introduces changes to the protocol for a subsequent phase. The concentration of the solution is adjusted to 30 mg/mL, and the infusion rate is increased to 3 mL/min. Given the modifications to the infusion method, which among the following pharmacokinetic parameters related to Y is expected to change?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Steady state plasma concentration attained

  1. Half-life: This is an intrinsic property of the drug and does not change based on dose or administration rate. Thus, changing the dose or infusion rate will not affect the half-life of the substance.
  2. Plasma concentration when the steady-state concentration is attained: The steady-state concentration is directly proportional to the rate of drug administration and inversely proportional to its clearance. Given that the rate of administration has been increased, the steady-state concentration will also increase.
  3. Time required to reach the steady-state concentration: For drugs that follow first-order kinetics, the time to reach steady state is dependent on the drug's half-life, not the dose or infusion rate. Typically, it takes about 4-5 half-lives to reach a steady-state concentration. Therefore, the time to reach steady state will remain unchanged.
  4. Total body clearance: This is another intrinsic property of the drug. It remains unchanged regardless of alterations in dosing or administration rate.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is evaluated at a follow-up visit. Two days ago, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and started on trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She has mild dysuria but is otherwise asymptomatic. Medical history is significant for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, chronic kidney disease, and hypertension. Other medications are atorvastatin and enalapril, which she has been taking for 5 years. Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are unremarkable. Laboratory studies performed 3 months ago showed a blood urea nitrogen level of 20 mg/dL (7.1 mmol/L) and a serum creatinine level of 1.3 mg/dL (115 µmol/L).

 

Today's laboratory studies:

Hemoglobin A1c 6.0 %

Blood urea nitrogen 19 mg/dL (6.8 mmol/L)

Creatinine 1.6 mg/dL (141.4 µmol/L)

Urinalysis No blood, protein, or erythrocytes

Urine albumin-creatinine ratio <30 mg/g

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. No further management

 

No further management is needed for this patient whose elevated serum creatinine levels are due to trimethoprim. Trimethoprim reduces proximal tubular secretion of creatinine, which results in a reversible increase in serum creatinine that does not affect the glomerular filtration rate. Other drugs that may cause a similar effect include cimetidine, dolutegravir, cobicistat, and tyrosine kinase inhibitors. As in this case, evaluation of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) may be helpful in these types of scenarios; if the serum creatinine level has increased in the presence of one of these offending drugs, a lack of concordant increase in BUN represents a clue that the increase in serum creatinine is medication induced and reversible. In the absence of other signs of kidney disease (e.g., normal urinalysis and albumin-creatinine ratio, as seen in this patient), no further evaluation is required.

 

Discontinuing enalapril (Option B) is not required. This patient has been taking enalapril for 5 years, and it is unlikely that this medication has caused an acute elevation in serum creatinine levels.

 

Discontinuing trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Option C) is not required. The increase of serum creatinine level represents a known and reversible medication effect of trimethoprim that does not affect the glomerular filtration rate.

 

Measurement of a fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) (Option D) is helpful in distinguishing causes of acute kidney injury (e.g., differentiating prerenal acute kidney injury from acute tubular necrosis). However, in this patient, serum creatinine has increased without a concomitant increase in BUN; the patient likely has a medication-induced transient elevation in serum creatinine due to trimethoprim. Therefore, measurement of FENa will not provide additionally relevant clinical information.

choices.text: 50% of patients present with joint disease prior to skin involvement
Bony erosions are not commonly seen on radiographs
Joint disease correlates with severity of skin involvement
Rheumatoid factor is commonly absent

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with concerns about changes in his nails, which have persisted for several years. The nails show onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed) and pitting. He recalls receiving treatment with terbinafine from an outside physician with no relief. On closer examination, you notice well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales on his elbows and knees. Additionally, he reports morning shoulder stiffness and back pain that lasts 1-2 hours but tends to improve with activity. Which of the following is true regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rheumatoid factor is commonly absent

 

This patient has psoriatic Skin & nail changes and a history suggestive of Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA). Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthropathy associated with psoriasis.

 

Option D: In 80% of patients the rheumatoid factor is negative; however a positive rheumatoid factor may sometimes be seen.

 

Option A: 80% of patients present with skin disease first.

 

Option B: Large eccentric erosions are classically present on radiographs.

 

Option C: The severity of psoriasis does not always correlate with the severity of the joint disease in PsA.

questions.text: A 23-year-old, previously healthy man presents to the ER after sustaining a single gunshot wound to the left chest. The entrance wound is 3 cm inferior to the nipple and the exit wound is just below the scapula. A chest tube is placed that drains 400 mL of blood and continues to drain 50 to 75 mL/h during the initial resuscitation. Initial blood pressure of 70/0 mm Hg has responded to 2-L crystalloid and is now 100/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Chest x-ray reveals a re-expanded lung and no free air under the diaphragm. Which of the following is the best next step in his management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Exploratory laparotomy

 

Gunshot wounds to the lower chest are often associated with intra-abdominal injuries; any patient with a gunshot wound below the level of T4 should be subjected to abdominal exploration. The domes of the diaphragm are at the level of the nipples, and the diaphragm can rise to the level of T4 during maximal expiration. Exploratory thoracotomy is not automatically indicated because most parenchymal lung injuries will stop bleeding and heal spontaneously with tube thoracostomy alone. Indications for thoracic exploration for bleeding are 1500 mL of blood on initial chest tube placement or persistent bleeding at a rate of 200 mL/h for 4 hours or 100 mL/h for 8 hours. Peritoneal lavage is not indicated even when the abdominal examination is unremarkable. As many as 25% of patients with negative physical findings and negative peritoneal lavage will have significant intra-abdominal injuries in this setting. These injuries include damage to the colon, kidney, pancreas, aorta, and diaphragm.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the orthopedic clinic with a chief complaint of recurrent and painful swellings in various muscle groups. He reports that these episodes have been occurring since childhood, with the first episode observed around the age of 5. On examination, you note palpable, firm, and immobile masses within the muscles of his upper arms, thighs, and back. The patient's range of motion in these affected muscle groups is significantly restricted. The skeletal survey of the patient is shown here. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Myositis ossificans progressiva

 

This patient's clinical presentation, with recurrent and painful muscle swellings that progress to form firm, immobile masses within the muscles, along with significant joint immobility, is characteristic of myositis ossificans progressiva (Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva). This rare genetic disorder leads to the progressive heterotopic ossification of soft tissues, including muscles, tendons, and ligaments, resulting in severe functional limitations. Muscular dystrophy (option A) typically presents with progressive muscle weakness but does not involve heterotopic ossification. Myositis ossificans traumatica (option B) is a condition where bone forms within muscle tissue as a result of trauma, but it is not typically recurrent or seen in multiple muscle groups. Rheumatoid arthritis (option D) primarily affects the joints and does not involve the formation of osseous masses within muscles.

choices.text: Disease progression to acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
Normal variation in CLL cell surface markers

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) presents with worsening fatigue and lymphocytosis. Dr Sparsh performed his flow cytometry of peripheral blood which reveals an increased number of CD19+CD5+ B lymphocytes. What is the most likely interpretation of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Transformation to Richter transformation

 

In chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), the characteristic immunophenotype of the leukemic cells is CD19+CD5+, indicating B-cell origin with co-expression of the CD5 marker. Transformation to Richter transformation refers to the development of an aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), in a patient with CLL. It is associated with a poor prognosis and is characterized by the rapid growth of large B lymphocytes. Therefore, an increased number of CD19+CD5+ B lymphocytes in a patient with CLL may suggest transformation to Richter transformation rather than disease progression to acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), remission, or normal variation in CLL cell surface markers.

choices.text: Mala N: Ethinyl estradiol 0.03 mcg, Levonorgestrel 0.15 mcg

questions.text: Incorrect combination about Contraceptive composition is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mala N: Ethinyl estradiol 0.03 mcg, Levonorgestrel 0.15 mcg

  • Mala N is a combined OCP containing  Ethinyl estradiol 30 mcg and Levonorgestrel 150 mcg
  • NORPLANT: is a subdermal implant contraceptive which has 6 silastic capsules containing 35 mg LNG each
  • Vaginal sponge: TODAY (brand name) combines barrier and spermicidal methods to prevent conception. It is a small polyurethane sponge 5 cm × 2.5 cm which is saturated with 1000 mg of spermicide ‘Non-oxynol–9’
  • Progestasert is a 3rd Generation IUD (Medicated/Bio-active IUD) filled with 38 mg progesterone. The rate of hormone release is 65 mcg per day.

choices.text: A 57 year old non-diabetic male
A 45 year old obese person with type 2 diabetes mellitus
A 50-year-old woman with Polycystic Ovary Disease and impaired glucose tolerance.
A 65-year-old man with type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: Dr. Vivek Jain is reviewing medications at a community health camp. One of his tasks is to counsel on the effective use of glipizide for managing elevated blood sugar levels. Among the attendees, there's a diverse group of patients with various health profiles. Dr. Jain recognizes that glipizide can reduce blood sugar in many patient groups, but there's one category of individuals in which it might not have a notable effect. Which of the following patients is LEAST likely to experience a significant reduction in blood sugar levels with glipizide?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A 65-year-old man with type 1 diabetes.

 

Given the options and focusing on glipizide, the correct answer should be the individual with type 1 diabetes, as glipizide works by stimulating the pancreas to produce more insulin. In type 1 diabetes, there's a destruction of beta cells, meaning there's minimal to no insulin production capability left in the pancreas.

  • Non-diabetics (a): While it's not common practice to administer glipizide to non-diabetics, those with impaired glucose tolerance or at high risk for diabetes might still have functioning beta cells that glipizide could stimulate to a degree. However, it's crucial to be cautious to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • Obese diabetics (b): Glipizide is effective for type 2 diabetics, including obese patients. It stimulates insulin secretion, which in turn helps reduce blood glucose levels.
  • Woman with PCOS (c): Women with PCOS with impaired glucose tolerance might benefit from glipizide due to the drug's ability to stimulate insulin secretion.
  • Individual with type 1 diabetes (d): This is where glipizide would be least effective. Type 1 diabetics have little to no functional beta cells in the pancreas. Hence, a drug that works by stimulating insulin production would not be beneficial, as there's minimal capability left to produce insulin.

choices.text: Elevated CSF pressure with increased white cell counts
Elevated polymorphonuclear cells with high protein levels
Elevated lymphocytes with normal glucose levels
Normal CSF pressure with a positive Gram stain reaction

questions.text: A 32-year-old man who lives in downtown Philadelphia presents to his physician with a 4-day history of terrible headache, fever, and stiff neck. He has always been in good health and attributes this to his healthy eating habits and his daily running through the city parks near his apartment. The physician suspects the man may have cryptococcal meningitis and collects CSF for examination. Which of the following results would you most likely expect from this patient’s CSF studies?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Elevated CSF pressure with increased white cell counts

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 6-mm basal cell carcinoma on the tip of his nose. He is scheduled to undergo excision of the tumor in the operating room with repair of the defect using skin and subcutaneous tissue from his earlobe. Which of the following terms most appropriately describes this form of reconstructive surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Composite graft

 

A composite tissue graft contains tissue in addition to the epidermis and dermis. Depending on the donor site, it can contain subcutaneous fat, cartilage, and even muscle. This makes it ideal for deeper defects in which a partial-thickness or full-thickness skin graft would give a poor cosmetic outcome. A flap is a vascularized piece of tissue that is mobilized from its original site to another location. A free tissue flap involves severing the original blood supply with anastomosis to blood vessels in the recipient site. The remaining defect in this patient is too small to warrant the need for a flap.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of major depressive disorder and peptic ulcer disease is currently managed on both antidepressant and anti-ulcer therapies. She presents to the clinic with tremors, confusion, and agitation. The physician suspects an unintended drug interaction. Which combination of antidepressant and anti-ulcer medication is most likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluoxetine + Cimetidine.

  • Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) commonly used to treat major depressive disorder. By itself, it can raise serotonin levels in the CNS.
  • Cimetidine, an H2 receptor antagonist, is known to inhibit many of the cytochrome P450 enzymes, particularly CYP2D6. Fluoxetine is metabolized by CYP2D6. If its metabolism is inhibited (e.g., by Cimetidine), it can lead to increased levels of Fluoxetine, and thus, the risk of serotonin syndrome is enhanced.

For the other options:

  • B) Pantoprazole, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), doesn't have a significant interaction with Sertraline to induce serotonin syndrome.
  • C) While Amitriptyline does affect serotonin levels, Ranitidine (another H2 receptor antagonist) doesn't significantly inhibit its metabolism to induce serotonin syndrome.
  • D) Bupropion's mechanism of action is mainly through norepinephrine and dopamine; Omeprazole doesn't have a significant interaction to induce serotonin syndrome with Bupropion.

choices.text: Increased intrapulmonary shunting leading to ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
Insufficient tidal volume delivery causing alveolar collapse and reduced gas exchange.
Positive pressure ventilation causing air trapping and dynamic hyperinflation.
Impaired surfactant production resulting in decreased lung compliance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath. The patient's arterial blood gases reveal a low partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) and a high partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2). The healthcare team decides to initiate mechanical ventilation to provide respiratory support. Which of the following best explains the phenomenon of "auto-PEEP" that can occur in patients with severe COPD during mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positive pressure ventilation causing air trapping and dynamic hyperinflation.

 

"Auto-PEEP" (auto-positive end-expiratory pressure) occurs when positive pressure ventilation prevents complete exhalation, leading to air trapping in the lungs during each respiratory cycle.

 

In patients with severe COPD, airflow limitation and increased resistance impede the normal exhalation process.

 

Positive pressure applied during mechanical ventilation can lead to dynamic hyperinflation, where the volume of trapped gas increases with each breath.

 

This phenomenon can lead to overdistension of alveoli, reduced lung compliance, and worsened ventilation-perfusion matching.

 

The other options are incorrect

 

A. "Intrapulmonary shunting" refers to blood bypassing ventilated alveoli, leading to hypoxemia, but it does not explain the mechanism of auto-PEEP.

 

B. "Insufficient tidal volume delivery" can cause atelectasis due to alveolar collapse, but it does not specifically explain the phenomenon of auto-PEEP.

 

D. "Impaired surfactant production" affects lung compliance and alveolar stability, but it is not directly related to the dynamic hyperinflation observed in auto-PEEP.

choices.text: A father and an uncle (same side of the family) with colon cancer
A father and grandfather (same side of the family) with colon cancer
A father and 2 uncles (same side of the family) with colon cancer
A father, uncle, and grandfather (same side of the family) with colon cancer at 50 years of age

questions.text: A 24-year-old man whose father was just diagnosed with colon cancer presents to his family physician to discuss screening colonoscopy. His physician suspects that he has hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch syndrome and recommends screening colonoscopy beginning at age 25. Which of the following is most supportive of a clinical diagnosis of HNPCC?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A father, uncle, and grandfather (same side of the family) with colon cancer at 50 years of age

 

The Amsterdam criteria are used to clinically diagnose hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) and consist of (a) at least 3 relatives with histologically confirmed colorectal cancer, one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other; (b) involvement of at least 2 successive generations; and (c) diagnosis of at least one of the cancers before age 50. Screening for patients with HNPCC should start either between the ages of 20 and 25 or 10 years earlier than the youngest family member with colorectal cancer, whichever comes earlier. This recommendation differs than that for the average-risk patient, for whom screening should begin at age 50.

questions.text: A patient while eating fish felt something suddenly stuck in her throat and came to ER. She is having a pricky sensation in her throat. She was advised an X-ray which is given below. Find the location of foreign body.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. None

 

1 – Hyoid bone

 

2 – Cricoid ossification

 

3 – Mandible ramus margin

 

There is no foreign body in this x-ray. Sometimes, the fish bone may traumatise by pricking in the mucosa of the pharynx. Due to local oedema, patient will have a sensation of having something in the throat. But, on x-ray, we may not visualise any foreign body. In that case, just assure the patient and give anti-inflammatory medication. Within 2-3 days, it will get resolved.

choices.text: CT of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis
Excisional biopsy of a cervical lymph node
Fine-needle aspiration of a cervical lymph node
PET/CT of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is evaluated for painless lymphadenopathy of several months' duration. He has no other symptoms. Infectious work-up was negative, and the lymphadenopathy did not improve. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he takes no medications. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There are multiple rubbery lymph nodes in bilateral cervical, inguinal, and axillary areas varying in size from 1 to 3 cm. There is no hepatomegaly or splenomegaly. Results of complete blood count, comprehensive chemistry profile, HIV testing, and measurement of lactate dehydrogenase level are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to perform next?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Excisional biopsy of a cervical lymph node

 

An excisional lymph node biopsy (Option B) would be the optimal approach in this patient with high suspicion for lymphoma. Although small regional lymph nodes may be palpable in otherwise healthy adults, the presence of generalized lymphadenopathy (involving more than one region) may be a feature of a number of systemic diseases, including lymphoma, infection (HIV, tuberculosis), and autoimmune disease. An excisional biopsy is most likely to provide an adequate sample to assess the lymph node architecture and make a diagnosis as well as to obtain material for any additional testing (such as flow cytometry, immunohistochemistry, and molecular genetic testing). Although fine-needle aspiration and core needle biopsies may help support or make a diagnosis of malignancies other than lymphoma, these approaches provide only limited information; they may not provide adequate material to define nodal architecture that can distinguish various subtypes of lymphoma, such as separating follicular from diffuse forms Ultimately, this patient may require a CT or PET to complete his staging (Options A, D), however, it is more appropriate to establish a diagnosis first and then determine what is needed for staging purposes.

 

In patients with suspected lymphoma in whom excisional node biopsy cannot be easily or safely done, such as those with intrathoracic or intra-abdominal disease, fine-needle aspiration (Option C) and cytology and core needle biopsies may be used initially. Flow cytometry may help further confirm or characterize a diagnosis of lymphoma by demonstrating monoclonal populations or aberrant immunophenotypes, but it is often not adequate to make a specific diagnosis. Molecular diagnostic techniques may also help make a diagnosis with smaller tissue samples. However, in this patient with easily accessible peripheral adenopathy, excisional biopsy (preferably of the cervical or axillary node rather than the inguinal node) has the highest yield.

choices.text: Fiberoptic laryngoscopy to rule out bilateral vocal cord paralysis
Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics and debridement of the wound

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of previous right thyroidectomy for a benign thyroid nodule now undergoes completion thyroidectomy for a suspicious thyroid mass. Several hours postoperatively, she develops progressive swelling under the incision, stridor, and difficulty breathing. Orotracheal intubation is successful. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wound exploration

 

The clinical presentation is consistent with a wound hematoma and necessitates exploration of the wound, drainage of the hematoma, and identification and control of any bleeding vessels. If airway control is unable to be obtained prior to the operating room, the wound should be opened at the bedside. Bilateral vocal cord dysfunction can be a cause of postoperative stridor and difficulty breathing, particularly after reoperative surgery; however, bilateral vocal cord dysfunction should manifest immediately after extubation. Hypocalcemia can occur in post-thyroidectomy due to ischemia or accidental removal of parathyroid tissue but is typically transient. Symptoms of hypocalcemia are usually neuromuscular and cardiac in nature.

choices.text: Termination of the pregnancy followed by modified radical mastectomy
Immediate administration of chemotherapy followed by modified radical mastectomy after delivery of the baby
Breast conservation therapy in third trimester

questions.text: A 33-year-old pregnant woman notices a persistent, painless lump in the left breast. On examination the left breast has a single mobile mass without evidence of skin changes or lymphadenopathy in the neck or axilla. An ultrasound demonstrates a solid, 1-cm mass in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. A core-needle biopsy shows invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient is in her first trimester of pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Modified radical mastectomy

 

The most appropriate treatment is immediate surgery. There is no evidence that general anesthesia and nonabdominal surgery increase premature labour and therefore surgery should not be delayed until after delivery of the baby. Breast conservation therapy is not routinely recommended during pregnancy because the radioactivity may harm the fetus. Radiation therapy is contraindicated in all trimesters of pregnancy. Patients in later stages of pregnancy, however, can start radiation therapy shortly after delivery, and some may be candidates for breast-conserving surgery and adjuvant radiotherapy. Administration of chemotherapy to a pregnant patient should be delayed until after the first trimester due to the increased risk of fetal abnormalities. Chemotherapy does not appear to increase the risk of congenital malformation when given in the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Elective termination of the pregnancy to receive appropriate therapy without the risk to the fetus is no longer routinely recommended because it has not been demonstrated to improve survival.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is evaluated for anemia discovered during a preoperative assessment for total hip arthroplasty. She has no other medical problems and has no symptoms other than hip pain. Her only medication is paracetamol. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Restricted range of motion of the left hip is noted. Laboratory studies:

 

Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL

Leukocyte count 5000/µL

MCV 70 fL

Platelet count 600,000/µL

Reticulocyte count 1%

Ferritin 12 ng/mL

Peripheral smear: microcytosis and anisopoikilocytosis.

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Colonoscopy and esophagogastroduodenoscopy

 

The most appropriate management of this patient with iron deficiency anemia is to perform colonoscopy and esophagogastroduodenoscopy (Option B). A low mean corpuscular volume (MCV), low serum ferritin level, and peripheral blood smear showing microcytosis and anisopoikilocytosis are virtually diagnostic of iron deficiency. A serum ferritin level of less than 14 ng/mL (14 µg/L) is highly specific (99%) for iron deficiency but has a low sensitivity (59%). A serum ferritin cutoff value of 45 ng/mL (45 µg/L) increases the sensitivity but reduces the specificity. Patients with iron deficiency may be asymptomatic or experience fatigue, lack of a sense of well-being, and decreased exercise tolerance; physical examination may be normal with glossitis, stomatitis, and koilonychia variably present in more severe deficiency. Other than menstrual blood loss, gastrointestinal bleeding is the most common cause of iron deficiency, and bidirectional endoscopy is recommended in all men and postmenopausal women with iron deficiency anemia.

 

Although assessment of bone marrow iron stores with Prussian blue staining of a bone marrow biopsy is the traditional gold standard for the diagnosis of iron deficiency, this test is seldom necessary to make the diagnosis (Option A). The combination of anemia, low MCV, low serum ferritin level, and peripheral blood smear findings confirms iron deficiency in this patient.

 

Erythropoietin testing is most useful in evaluating the cause of anemia with a low reticulocyte count in patients with mild kidney disease because erythropoietin levels will be low if kidney disease is contributory (Option C). Numerous conditions, however, may cause a low reticulocyte count, including myelodysplasia; aplastic anemia; and vitamin B12, folate, and iron deficiencies. This patient has iron deficiency as a cause of the low reticulocyte count and erythropoietin testing is not indicated.

 

The JAK2 mutation (Option D) is present in about 50% of patients with essential thrombocythemia, which should be considered in patients with sustained platelet count elevation greater than 450,000/µL (450 × 109/L). Secondary causes of thrombocytosis are far more common than essential thrombocythemia and include iron deficiency, hemolysis, medications, recent splenectomy, and inflammatory processes, including infection and malignancy. In this patient, iron deficiency is the cause of thrombocytosis, and JAK2 mutation testing is not indicated

choices.text: Right hemicolectomy with local resection of the liver metastasis
Closure of the abdomen followed by chemotherapy
Right hemicolectomy with postoperative radiation therapy to the liver

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was discovered to have a hepatic flexure colon cancer during a colonoscopy for anemia requiring transfusions. Upon exploration of his abdomen in the operating room, an unexpected discontinuous 3-cm metastasis is discovered in the edge of the right lobe of the liver. Preoperatively, the patient was counseled of this possibility and the surgical options. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right hemicolectomy with local resection of the liver metastasis

 

Five-year survival rates of 25% have been reported after synchronous resection of primary colorectal cancers and liver metastases. Because approximately 5% of colorectal cancers are associated with resectable hepatic metastases, appropriate preoperative discussion should include obtaining permission for removal of synchronous peripheral hepatic lesions if they are found. Adequate local resection, either by wedge or by limited partial hepatectomy, may be carried out whenever no extrahepatic disease is found and the hepatic lesion is technically removable. Any option that leaves the symptomatic colon cancer (bleeding) would be unacceptable. Radiation therapy has little to offer in colon cancer or its hepatic metastases.

questions.text: 65-year-old male complains of bilateral visual difficulty that has progressed over the last year. Funduscopy reveals small yellow retinal lesions clustered in the macula. Which of the following would you expect most on visual field examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Central scotomas

 

Macular lesions impair central vision and result in central scotomata. The term scotoma refers to any visual defect surrounded by a relatively unimpaired field of vision. Scotomas occur due to pathologic processes that involve parts of the retina or optic nerve. Examples of such processes include demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis, diabetic retinopathy and retinitis pigmentosa. Pathologic processes that involve the entire optic nerve lead to monocular blindness. The patient described in this clinical vignette is likely to have macular degeneration (MD). This disorder is frequently age-related, and is the most common cause of blind ness in people over 50 years old in the US. Macular degeneration is characterized by progressive loss of central vision due to deposition of fatty tissue (drusen) behind the retina (dry MD) and neovascularization of the retina (wet MD).

questions.text: A 30-day-old female baby, born at full-term, to nonconsanguinous parents, presented with a history of feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. There was a history of respiratory distress and cyanosis at birth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital pyriform aperture stenosis

 

Congenital pyriform aperture stenosis (CPAS) is a rare medical condition that affects the nasal passages in infants. It is characterized by the narrowing or closure of the pyriform aperture, which is the bony opening in the skull through which the nasal passages pass. This narrowing or closure can obstruct the flow of air through the nasal passages and cause breathing difficulties in affected infants. It is associated with a central incisor as shown in the image.

choices.text: Colicky pain abdomen with vomiting
Painless limp on right

questions.text: What is the likely clinical complaint of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inguino-scrotal swelling

 

The X-ray shows B/L gas shadows in the inguino-scrotal region suggestive of bowel loops which represent herniation of bowel loops.

choices.text: Low molecular weight antigen

questions.text: A 26-year-old man develops dysuria and purulent urethral discharge following unprotected sex with a new partner. Nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. The patient develops antibody against the bacterial pili that enhance attachment to host cells. His symptoms resolve with adequate treatment. His partner does not receive treatment. Several weeks later, the patient develops N gonorrhoeae reinfection after repeat exposure to the same partner. Which of the following is the most likely reason for the lack of long-lasting immunity against the bacteria despite antibody formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Antigenic variation

 

Gonococci use their pili to mediate adherence to the mucosal epithelium. Through antigenic variation, each gonococcus can modify the pilus protein expressed, thereby avoiding host defenses (to some degree) and making vaccination directed against the pilus protein difficult.

questions.text: 24-year-old female presents to your office with burning urination, urgency, and frequency. She is sexually active. Urine cultures show catalase-positive, gram-positive cocci. The organism responsible for this patient's symptoms is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Novobiocin resistant

 

S. aprophyticus is responsible for almost half of all UTIs in sexually active young women. Staphylococcus saprophyticus belongs to coagulase-negative staphylococci and is unique among these because it is resistant to novobiocin.

choices.text: Graft B cell sensitization against host MHC antigens
Graft T cell sensitization against host MHC antigens
Host B cell sensitization against graft MHC antigens
Host T cell sensitization against graft MHC antigens

questions.text: 55-year-old man with end-stage hepatitis C virus infection undergoes orthotopic liver transplantation from a deceased donor. The patient has no perioperative complications and is discharged from the hospital on appropriate immunosuppressant medications. One week after the surgery, he develops nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea. Physical examination shows a painful maculopapular rash over his neck, back and extremities that extends to the palms and soles. Endoscopic evaluation reveals multiple ulcerations of the intestinal mucosa. Which of the following is he most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Graft T cell sensitization against host MHC antigens

 

Graft-versus-host disease can occur following transplantation of organs rich in lymphocytes (eg, liver). T lymphocytes found in the donor organ become sensitized against the MHC antigens of the recipient and subsequently attack the host's tissues. The skin, liver, and gastrointestinal tract are most frequently affected.

questions.text: 33-year-old female is being followed by her neurologist for her multiple sclerosis. She was initially diagnosed with relapsing remitting subtype after an episode of visual disturbance and an episode of paralysis. in her study of autoimmune diseases she encounters the topic of lymphocyte development and comes across a question which she poses to her neurologist during a routine follow-up visit: During the process of T-lymphocyte maturation, T cell receptors of many lymphocytes demonstrate a very high-affinity interaction with MHC molecules expressed on thymic medullary epithelial and dendritic cells. What process do these lymphocytes undergo at this time?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Negative selection

 

Exp: The process of negative selection in T cell maturation is essential for eliminating T cells that bind to self MHC or self antigens with overly high affinity. This process occurs in the thymic medulla. If these cells were permitted to survive they would likely induce immune and inflammatory reactions against self antigens leading to autoimmune disease.

choices.text: Same as the general population

questions.text: A healthy couple, who recently emigrated from Eastern Europe, bring their 3-year-old son to the office for evaluation of an eczematous rash. On examination, the child also shows signs of intellectual disability and gait abnormality and has a musty body odor. What is the likelihood that this couple's next child will be affected with the same disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1/4

 

Intellectual disability, gait or posture abnormality, eczema, and a musty body odor are signs of phenyketonuria (PKU). PKU is autosomal recessive disease caused by mutation of the gene that codes for phenylalanine hydroxylase. Because PKU is inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, both of the healthy parents must be heterozygous carriers of the mutation. The probability that their next child will inherit the disease is:

 

P’ = probability that the mother transmits the mutant allele = 1/2

 

P”= probability that the father transmits the mutant allele = 1/2

 

The probability that a child will inherit a mutant allele from each carrier parent is equal to p’ x p” = 1/4, as these are independent events.

questions.text:
26-year-old woman is being evaluated for a possible inherited disorder. She has a 6-year history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and a year ago, she had partial loss of vision due to an occipital infarction. Her mother has chronic intermittent muscle weakness and lactic acidosis and her maternal uncle has hemiplegia. Skeletal muscle biopsy of the patient shows ragged-appearing muscle fibers. After further evaluation, all the affected family members are found to suffer from the same inherited disease. Pedigree analysis is shown in the image below.

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the variability of clinical manifestations in the affected family members?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Heteroplasmy

 

The presence of lactic acidosis and ragged skeletal muscle fibers histologically suggests a mitochondrial myopathy. Variable clinical expressions in affected family members can occur due to heteroplasmy, which is the coexistence of distinct versions of mitochondrial genomes in an individual cell.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and a palpable mass in the abdomen. Dr Zainab did his imaging which reveals a well-circumscribed, heterogeneously enhancing mass arising from the muscular wall of the stomach. She suggested a biopsy of the mass. Dr Sparsh reported bland spindle cells with faintly eosinophilic cytoplasm in a syncytial pattern; and elongated nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).

 

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are the most common mesenchymal tumors of the gastrointestinal tract. They most commonly arise in the stomach, followed by the small intestine. GISTs are characterized by bland spindle cells with faintly eosinophilic cytoplasm in a syncytial pattern; and elongated nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli. Sometimes spindle cells have a "starry-sky" appearance, reflecting the presence of epithelioid cells interspersed among spindle cells. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for CD117 (c-KIT), a receptor tyrosine kinase.

choices.text: 5 - 10% blasts in bone marrow or peripheral blood
Persistent platelet count < 100,000 related to therapy
Additional clonal chromosomal abnormalities like second Ph chromosome, trisomy 8, isochromosome 17q

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to his primary care physician Dr Dileep with complaints of fatigue, easy bruising, and night sweats. On physical examination, splenomegaly is noted. He is referred to Cerebellum Pathology Lab where the complete blood count reveals an elevated white blood cell count with a left shift, increased basophils, and increased myeloid cells. She reports sudden onset of worsening symptoms for last 5 days.  Which of the following is a criterion for the diagnosis of accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia according to WHO 2017 criteria?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Additional clonal chromosomal abnormalities like second Ph chromosome, trisomy 8, isochromosome 17q

choices.text: This is a case of gastrinoma with high gastrin secretion resulting in hypersecretion of hydrochloric acid.
Prilosec is an example of a proton pump inhibitor which may cause decrease Vit B12 absorption.
In this patient due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency myelination of anterior spinothalamic tract has been affected.
On haematological examination Increased mean corpuscular volume (MCV, >100 fL) and mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) and polymorphonuclear cells with multiple lobes are found.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient presented with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, which is often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple peptic ulcers in the duodenal bulb. Laboratory tests show elevated gastrin levels. She was given Prilosec for a long time. She was also consuming a vegetarian diet and now presented with tiredness & palpitations since a month. She complained of progressive sensory loss in her lower extremities. Neurological examination reveals impaired vibratory sensation in both legs. An MRI of the spinal cord shows no structural abnormalities. On blood examination she had following haematological slide was found. All of the following statements are correct in this case except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. In this patient due to Vitamin B 12 deficiency myelination of anterior spinothalamic tract has been affected.

  • This is a case of Gastrinoma, Zollinger Ellison syndrome.
  • The DOC for ZES is PPI.
  • Prilosec is a PPI which inhibit gastric acid secretion.
  • PPIs such as Omeprazole, if used for more than 6 months can cause Vit B12 deficiency.
  • Also this patient is vegetarian which indicates for Vit B12 deficiency.
  • Given symptoms indicate Vitamin B12 deficiency leading to megaloblastic anaemia.
  • In haematological slide Hypersegmented neutrophils are visible.

  • In this patient vitamin B12 deficiency leads to Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. 
  • It is characterized by degeneration of the dorsal column and the lateral column of the spinal cord due to demyelination.
  • Symptoms of progressive sensory loss lower extremities and loss of  vibratory sensation in both legs indicates involvement of Fasciculus Gracilis and cuneatus , which are dorsal column tracts in spinal cord.
  • Fasciculus Gracilis and cuneatus are located in dorsal white column not in anterior white column, hence option C is incorrect statement, rest all are correct.

questions.text: 4-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a routine health maintenance visit. The patient has been toilet trained for 2 years. He sees a pediatric dentist every 6 months and has no dental caries. The boy's mother describes him as a picky eater. She states that he prefers to eat bananas, apples, and bread but dislikes vegetables, meat, and milk products. He participates in a weekly community soccer league. He had acute gastroenteritis twice during infancy, but has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications. The boy lives with his mother, who is a single parent, and 2 older brothers. He attends preschool 5 days per week and is learning to write his name. His mother says that he is not a social child and prefers to play with his best friend or his brothers. Which of the following preventive health measures is most appropriate at this visit?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Visual acuity testing

 

Vision is evaluated at every well-child visit, as untreated eye abnormalities during the first few years of life can lead to permanent vision. Visual acuity testing is performed routinely at age 4 but can be performed as early as age 3 in cooperative children. The Snellen chart is the gold standard, although the HOTV (4-letter) or LEA (picture) chart may be used for young children with limited or no ability to identify letters. Visual acuity worse than 20/40 at age 4 or worse than 20/30 at age 25 should prompt ophthalmologic evaluation for refractive errors.

questions.text: ICT enabled Adherence System under National TB Elimination program is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DOTS-99

  • DOTS-99: ICT-based Adherence Support is a low-cost approach for monitoring and improving TB medication adherence. Each anti-TB blister pack is wrapped in a custom envelope, which includes hidden phone numbers that are visible only when doses are dispensed. After taking daily medication, patients make a free call (from his pre-registered mobile number) to the hidden phone number, yielding high confidence that the dose was “in-hand” and has been taken.
  • NIKSHAY: ICT-based Surveillance Support (Online monitoring software) to get notification of TB cases at diagnosis from both public and private sector including drug resistant TB patients. There is continuous monitoring and treatment adherence for all TB patients registered. It enables tracking of all notified TB patients across TB care cycle, geographies, transfers and referrals.
  • NIKSHAY POSHAN YOJANA: Ministry of Health & Family Welfare (MoHFW) has launched the Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) scheme for nutritional support to tuberculosis patients as Nikshay Poshan Yojana (NPY). Under NPY, a financial incentive of Rs 500 per month is provided to each notified TB patient for the entire duration of his treatment.
  • NIKSHAY MITRA: Launched on 9 September 2022, Nikshay Mitra is a crowd-sourced programme that allows organisations and individuals to 'adopt' TB patients, and support them directly with nutrition supplies, and vocational training. Donors include co-operative societies, corporates, elected representatives, individuals, institutions, non-governmental organisations, political parties and partners who can support by adopting the health facilities (for individual donor), blocks/urban wards/districts/States for accelerating the response against TB to complement the government efforts.
